For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. On one side, encode a polarization qubit; on the other, encode a qubit into two specific THz\u2010separated frequency modes. Perform a Bell\u2010state measurement that \u201cswaps\u201d the polarization qubit into the frequency\u2010bin DOF, effectively simulating a strong light\u2013matter coupling (polariton) interface between polarization and frequency. Then teleport that qubit onward.\n    b) Hybrid Node Network Emulating THz Strong Coupling via Ancillary High\u2010Dimensional Mode:\n       \u2013 Build a three\u2010node network A\u2013C\u2013B. A\u2013C share a 2D Bell pair, C\u2013B share a D\u2010dimensional Bell pair (D\u226b2), where the extra dimensions emulate matter excitations at THz energy splittings. At C, perform a joint measurement across the 2D and D\u2010dimensional systems (a \u201chybrid\u201d Bell measurement) that enacts an entanglement swap and simulates the strong coupling between light (2D) and matter (D\u2010dimensional THz manifold). This teleports A\u2019s qubit into B\u2019s high\u2010D mode.\n    c) Teleportation of a Qubit through Simulated Polaritonic Modes Using Ancillary THz\u2010Bin Photons:\n       \u2013 Prepare two three\u2010party entangled GHZ\u2010like links: one in polarization and one in THz\u2010frequency bins. Use ancillary THz\u2010frequency photons to mediate a three\u2010photon joint measurement that swaps entanglement between the polarization GHZ and the THz\u2010GHZ, simulating the formation and decay of polaritons under strong coupling. Then use that to teleport a polarization qubit from node A to node B via the THz network.\n  Step 2: Novelty & Obstacles:\n    a) Novel\u2014no prior Pytheus experiment mixes 2D polarization with THz\u2010spaced frequency bins in a swapping protocol. Obstacle: Pytheus requires abstract bins; however frequency bins are just abstract high\u2010dimensional modes, so feasible.\n    b) Novel\u2014hybrid Bell measurement between different dimensions; no direct analog in list. Obstacle: specifying a joint measurement across different subsystems is expressible as target amplitudes.\n    c) More complex\u2014GHZ in two DOFs and GHZ\u2010swap; likely too intricate and may strain Pytheus\u2019s loss\u2010function calibration.\n  Step 3: Pick (a) Frequency\u2010Bin Teleportation;\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it explicitly combines a two\u2010dimensional polarization qubit with a THz\u2010spaced high\u2010dimensional frequency\u2010bin entangled channel in an entanglement\u2010swapping/teleportation protocol. No previous Pytheus target mixes low\u2010D and high\u2010D modes in this manner or references THz spacing.\n  Step 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because:\n    \u2022 It defines an abstract two\u2010mode (polarization) system and an abstract N\u2010mode (frequency bins) system\u2014both allowed.\n    \u2022 The target is an entanglement swapping/teleportation of an abstract qubit, without focusing on physical state generation.\n    \u2022 No feedback control or cavities are needed\u2014only linear optics, probabilistic pair sources, and joint measurements.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription: Teleportation of a polarization qubit into a THz\u2010spaced frequency\u2010bin qudit via entanglement swapping, simulating a strong light\u2013matter coupling interface.\nExplanation:\n  We consider two distinct DOFs:\n    \u2013 Qubit (polarization) at node A.\n    \u2013 Qubit encoded into two THz\u2010separated frequency bins at node B.\n  We start with:\n    1) A polarization Bell pair between A (photon 0) and C (photon 1): |00>_pol + |11>_pol.\n    2) A 2\u2010bin frequency\u2010bin Bell pair between C (photon 2) and B (photon 3): |\u03c91,\u03c91> + |\u03c92,\u03c92>, where \u0394\u03c9 \u2248 THz.\n  Goal: teleport an arbitrary polarization state |\u03c8> on photon 0 to the two\u2010bin frequency qubit on detector 3.\n  Protocol:\n    \u2013 Alice (node A) holds photon 0 in unknown polarization |\u03c8>.\n    \u2013 Charlie at node C holds photons 1 and 2 (one in polarization, one in frequency bins).\n    \u2013 Charlie performs a joint Bell\u2010state measurement between photons 0 and 1 across polarization modes. This measurement swaps entanglement onto photons 2 (freq) and 0\u20131 pair, effectively imprinting |\u03c8> onto the frequency\u2010bin DOF of photon 2.\n    \u2013 Photon 2 is then already the teleported state in frequency bins; to complete, one can swap frequency\u2010bin labels via a swap test into photon 3.\n  Abstract Target Quantum (over four modes 0\u20133):\n    List amplitudes for the four\u2010mode basis that encode this teleportation (cf. standard qubit teleportation but replacing the teleported output mode with frequency\u2010bin labels).\n  Config Sketch:\n    \u2022 num_pre: 1 (one prepare stage with two probabilistic pair sources)\n    \u2022 num_anc: 0 (no extra ancillas; all four photons used)\n    \u2022 removed_connections: none (pairs define which detectors they feed)\n    \u2022 single_emitters: []\n    \u2022 heradling_out: None\n    \u2022 loss_func: \u2018cr\u2019 (complex\u2010amplitude matching)\n    \u2022 target_quantum: amplitudes for teleportation map      \t\nVisual Layout:\n  Pair source S1 \u2192 photons 0 & 1 (pol qubit)\n  Pair source S2 \u2192 photons 2 & 3 (freq qubit bins)\n  Linear\u2010optics network mixes modes of photons 0&1 at Charlie\u2019s Bell\u2010measurement block, leaving photons 2&3 untouched until output.\n  Detectors: [0(pol)] [1(pol)] [2(freq)] [3(freq)].\n\nThis network acts as an abstract teleportation channel from polarization (photon 0) to THz\u2010frequency\u2010bin qubit (photon 3), capturing the essence of strong light\u2013matter coupling via an entanglement swap between different modal spaces."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Catalytic Entanglement Amplification of Bell Pairs via a Squeezed-Reservoir Ancilla in Pure LOQC\n\nAbstract: We present a static LOQC circuit that catalytically amplifies the entanglement of two weak Bell pairs in modes (A,B) and (C,D) using a non-maximally entangled squeezed-reservoir ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082). By mixing modes {B,R\u2081} and {C,R\u2082} on two beam splitters and post-selecting on a fixed two-click photon-number pattern at detectors on B and C, the protocol realizes the target transformation in which modes A and D emerge in a stronger Bell-like state |00\u27e9+K(\u03b1,r)|11\u27e9 while the squeezed ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082) is returned unchanged.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a single-shot four-body stabilizer readout for the smallest toric-code plaquette by Bell-entangling each of four data photons with an ancilla photon and sending all ancilla modes through a 4\u00d74 passive interferometer equipped with number-resolving detectors. Heralded two-photon click patterns in even or odd detector pairs directly project the data qubits onto the \u00b11 eigenstates of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084, realizing a direct stabilizer measurement without any feed-forward or dynamic control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photon-Blockade-Assisted Entanglement Purification of Noisy Bell Pairs\n\nAbstract: We introduce a static linear-optical protocol that combines two probabilistic noisy Bell-pair sources with single-emitter photon-blockade nodes to suppress double-pair emissions and distill the target high-fidelity Bell state |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9=(|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9)/\u221a2. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description: Teleportation of a polarization qubit into a THz\u2010spaced frequency\u2010bin qudit via entanglement swapping, simulating a strong light\u2013matter coupling interface.\nExplanation:\n  We consider two distinct DOFs:\n    \u2013 Qubit (polarization) at node A.\n    \u2013 Qubit encoded into two THz\u2010separated frequency bins at node B.\n  We start with:\n    1) A polarization Bell pair between A (photon 0) and C (photon 1): |00>_pol + |11>_pol.\n    2) A 2\u2010bin frequency\u2010bin Bell pair between C (photon 2) and B (photon 3): |\u03c91,\u03c91> + |\u03c92,\u03c92>, where \u0394\u03c9 \u2248 THz.\n  Goal: teleport an arbitrary polarization state |\u03c8> on photon 0 to the two\u2010bin frequency qubit on detector 3.\n  Protocol:\n    \u2013 Alice (node A) holds photon 0 in unknown polarization |\u03c8>.\n    \u2013 Charlie at node C holds photons 1 and 2 (one in polarization, one in frequency bins).\n    \u2013 Charlie performs a joint Bell\u2010state measurement between photons 0 and 1 across polarization modes. This measurement swaps entanglement onto photons 2 (freq) and 0\u20131 pair, effectively imprinting |\u03c8> onto the frequency\u2010bin DOF of photon 2.\n    \u2013 Photon 2 is then already the teleported state in frequency bins; to complete, one can swap frequency\u2010bin labels via a swap test into photon 3.\n  Abstract Target Quantum (over four modes 0\u20133):\n    List amplitudes for the four\u2010mode basis that encode this teleportation (cf. standard qubit teleportation but replacing the teleported output mode with frequency\u2010bin labels).\n  Config Sketch:\n    \u2022 num_pre: 1 (one prepare stage with two probabilistic pair sources)\n    \u2022 num_anc: 0 (no extra ancillas; all four photons used)\n    \u2022 removed_connections: none (pairs define which detectors they feed)\n    \u2022 single_emitters: []\n    \u2022 heradling_out: None\n    \u2022 loss_func: \u2018cr\u2019 (complex\u2010amplitude matching)\n    \u2022 target_quantum: amplitudes for teleportation map      \t\nVisual Layout:\n  Pair source S1 \u2192 photons 0 & 1 (pol qubit)\n  Pair source S2 \u2192 photons 2 & 3 (freq qubit bins)\n  Linear\u2010optics network mixes modes of photons 0&1 at Charlie\u2019s Bell\u2010measurement block, leaving photons 2&3 untouched until output.\n  Detectors: [0(pol)] [1(pol)] [2(freq)] [3(freq)].\n\nThis network acts as an abstract teleportation channel from polarization (photon 0) to THz\u2010frequency\u2010bin qubit (photon 3), capturing the essence of strong light\u2013matter coupling via an entanglement swap between different modal spaces.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: While the use of two different DOFs (polarization\u2009\u2192\u2009frequency bins) is an interesting encoding trick, the core is just a standard teleportation via entanglement swapping, directly analogous to the \u201cTelecom-Band Frequency-Bin Teleportation MUX for Qubit\u2192Ququart Isometry\u201d in the ensemble. No new resource, superposition ordering, or non-trivial network primitive is introduced, and mapping between two qubit encodings is a trivial extension of known teleportation/swap protocols rather than a PRL-worthy novel experiment.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The scheme reduces to ordinary qubit teleportation between two DOFs and closely parallels existing frequency-bin teleportation proposals; you need a genuinely new network primitive, nonstandard resource conversion, or higher-order effect to be considered novel."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. On one side, encode a polarization qubit; on the other, encode a qubit into two specific THz\u2010separated frequency modes. Perform a Bell\u2010state measurement that \u201cswaps\u201d the polarization qubit into the frequency\u2010bin DOF, effectively simulating a strong light\u2013matter coupling (polariton) interface between polarization and frequency. Then teleport that qubit onward.\n    b) Hybrid Node Network Emulating THz Strong Coupling via Ancillary High\u2010Dimensional Mode:\n       \u2013 Build a three\u2010node network A\u2013C\u2013B. A\u2013C share a 2D Bell pair, C\u2013B share a D\u2010dimensional Bell pair (D\u226b2), where the extra dimensions emulate matter excitations at THz energy splittings. This teleports A\u2019s qubit into B\u2019s high\u2010D mode.\n    c) Teleportation of a Qubit through Simulated Polaritonic Modes Using Ancillary THz\u2010Bin Photons:\n       \u2013 Prepare two three\u2010party entangled GHZ\u2010like links: one in polarization and one in THz\u2010frequency bins. Obstacle: Pytheus requires abstract bins; however frequency bins are just abstract high\u2010dimensional modes, so feasible.\n    b) Novel\u2014hybrid Bell measurement between different dimensions; no direct analog in list. Obstacle: specifying a joint measurement across different subsystems is expressible as target amplitudes.\n    c) More complex\u2014GHZ in two DOFs and GHZ\u2010swap; likely too intricate and may strain Pytheus\u2019s loss\u2010function calibration.\n  Step 3: Pick (a) Frequency\u2010Bin Teleportation;\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it explicitly combines a two\u2010dimensional polarization qubit with a THz\u2010spaced high\u2010dimensional frequency\u2010bin entangled channel in an entanglement\u2010swapping/teleportation protocol. No previous Pytheus target mixes low\u2010D and high\u2010D modes in this manner or references THz spacing.\n  Step 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because:\n    \u2022 It defines an abstract two\u2010mode (polarization) system and an abstract N\u2010mode (frequency bins) system\u2014both allowed.\n    \u2022 The target is an entanglement swapping/teleportation of an abstract qubit, without focusing on physical state generation.\n    \u2022 No feedback control or cavities are needed\u2014only linear optics, probabilistic pair sources, and joint measurements.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription: Teleportation of a polarization qubit into a THz\u2010spaced frequency\u2010bin qudit via entanglement swapping, simulating a strong light\u2013matter coupling interface.\nExplanation:\n  We consider two distinct DOFs:\n    \u2013 Qubit (polarization) at node A.\n    \u2013 Qubit encoded into two THz\u2010separated frequency bins at node B.\n  We start with:\n    1) A polarization Bell pair between A (photon 0) and C (photon 1): |00>_pol + |11>_pol.\n    2) A 2\u2010bin frequency\u2010bin Bell pair between C (photon 2) and B (photon 3): |\u03c91,\u03c91> + |\u03c92,\u03c92>, where \u0394\u03c9 \u2248 THz.\n  Goal: teleport an arbitrary polarization state |\u03c8> on photon 0 to the two\u2010bin frequency qubit on detector 3.\n  Protocol:\n    \u2013 Alice (node A) holds photon 0 in unknown polarization |\u03c8>.\n    \u2013 Charlie at node C holds photons 1 and 2 (one in polarization, one in frequency bins).\n    \u2013 Charlie performs a joint Bell\u2010state measurement between photons 0 and 1 across polarization modes. This measurement swaps entanglement onto photons 2 (freq) and 0\u20131 pair, effectively imprinting |\u03c8> onto the frequency\u2010bin DOF of photon 2.\n    \u2013 Photon 2 is then already the teleported state in frequency bins; to complete, one can swap frequency\u2010bin labels via a swap test into photon 3.\n  Abstract Target Quantum (over four modes 0\u20133):\n    List amplitudes for the four\u2010mode basis that encode this teleportation (cf. standard qubit teleportation but replacing the teleported output mode with frequency\u2010bin labels).\n  Config Sketch:\n    \u2022 num_pre: 1 (one prepare stage with two probabilistic pair sources)\n    \u2022 num_anc: 0 (no extra ancillas; all four photons used)\n    \u2022 removed_connections: none (pairs define which detectors they feed)\n    \u2022 single_emitters: []\n    \u2022 heradling_out: None\n    \u2022 loss_func: \u2018cr\u2019 (complex\u2010amplitude matching)\n    \u2022 target_quantum: amplitudes for teleportation map      \t\nVisual Layout:\n  Pair source S1 \u2192 photons 0 & 1 (pol qubit)\n  Pair source S2 \u2192 photons 2 & 3 (freq qubit bins)\n  Linear\u2010optics network mixes modes of photons 0&1 at Charlie\u2019s Bell\u2010measurement block, leaving photons 2&3 untouched until output.\n  Detectors: [0(pol)] [1(pol)] [2(freq)] [3(freq)].\n\nThis network acts as an abstract teleportation channel from polarization (photon 0) to THz\u2010frequency\u2010bin qubit (photon 3), capturing the essence of strong light\u2013matter coupling via an entanglement swap between different modal spaces.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme reduces to ordinary qubit teleportation between two DOFs and closely parallels existing frequency-bin teleportation proposals; you need a genuinely new network primitive, nonstandard resource conversion, or higher-order effect to be considered novel.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to weave \u201cthz signal\u201d and \u201cstrong light\u2013matter coupling\u201d into a quantum network:\n    a) Teleport a polarization qubit into a THz\u2010frequency bin via one Bell\u2010swap (simple but similar to prior work).\n    b) Build a three\u2010node repeater that swaps polarization entanglement into a THz\u2010frequency high\u2010D link, then back to polarization\u2014yielding a polarization\u2013THz\u2013polarization swap chain.\n    c) Concentrate two polarization qubits into one THz\u2010frequency qudit by a joint entanglement\u2010swap measurement\u2014realizing a nontrivial isometry from two qubit modes into a four\u2010bin THz mode (\u201centanglement funneling\u201d).\n  Step 2: Quick novelty check:\n    a) Too close to ordinary teleportation.\n    b) Essentially a concatenation of entanglement swaps already explored.\n    c) Novel primitive: mapping two qubits \u2192 one qudit is not in the explored list; leverages THz\u2010separated modes to encode the qudit, and a single joint measurement to enact a \u201cstrong coupling\u201d\u2010like mixing of two excitations into one.\n  Step 3: Pick (c).\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it defines a new network primitive\u2014the coherent conversion (via entanglement swapping) of two separate polarization qubits into a single THz\u2010frequency qudit. No existing Pytheus target implements an isometry from two independently held qubits into one higher\u2010dimensional mode in this way.\n  Step 5: This idea is feasible in Pytheus because:\n    \u2022 All modes (polarization qubits and abstract THz\u2010frequency bins) are described purely abstractly.\n    \u2022 The target is a transformation (isometry) between modes, not state generation.\n    \u2022 It uses only probabilistic pair\u2010sources, linear optics, and joint measurements\u2014Pytheus\u2019s supported primitives.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription: Entanglement \u201cfunneling\u201d of two polarization qubits into one THz\u2010frequency qudit via a single joint swap measurement.\n\nExplanation:\n We label modes as follows:\n  \u2013 Node A holds photon 0 in polarization (qubit A).\n  \u2013 Node B holds photon 1 in polarization (qubit B).\n  \u2013 Node C holds photons 2&3: photon 2 is entangled in polarization with A, photon 3 entangled in polarization with B. These come from two independent Bell\u2010pair sources S1 (modes 0&2) and S2 (modes 1&3).\n  \u2013 Node D will output a single photon 4 encoded into four abstract frequency bins {\u03c90,\u03c91,\u03c92,\u03c93} with bin spacing \u0394\u03c9 \u2248 THz, i.e. a ququart.\n\nGoal: implement the isometry\n  |i\u27e9\u2080|j\u27e9\u2081 \u2192 |\u03c9_{2i + j}\u27e9\u2084   for i,j \u2208 {0,1},\nso that the joint polarization state of A&B is coherently \u201cfunnelled\u201d into one higher\u2010dimensional THz mode at D.\n\nProtocol (entanglement\u2010swap style):\n  1) Prepare S1: a polarization Bell pair on modes 0 & 2: |00>+|11>.\n  2) Prepare S2: a polarization Bell pair on modes 1 & 3: |00>+|11>.\n  3) At node C, interfere photons 2&3 in a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics network engineered to implement a joint measurement whose successful heralding projects those two photons onto one of four predefined two\u2010qubit Bell\u2010like basis states. The outcome determines which of the four frequency bins \u03c9_k at mode 4 carries the combined label (2i+j).\n  4) Conditioned on the heralded detection at C, photon 4 emerges in the target ququart state |\u03c9_{2i + j}\u27e9\u2084, faithfully representing the original two\u2010qubit state.\n\nAbstract Target Quantum:\n We define a four\u2010mode computational basis for modes 0,1,4:\n   { |0\u20800\u2081\u03c9\u2080\u2084>, |0\u20801\u2081\u03c9\u2081\u2084>, |1\u20800\u2081\u03c9\u2082\u2084>, |1\u20801\u2081\u03c9\u2083\u2084> } \n(with appropriate complex phases set by the joint measurement outcomes).\n The target amplitude list is then the identity map on that basis.\n\nConfig Sketch:\n  num_pre: 2                      # two pair sources\n  num_anc: 0                      # no extra ancillas beyond 4 photons\n  single_emitters: []\n  removed_connections: []         # sources only to their designated pairs\n  loss_func: 'cr'\n  samples: 10\n  target_quantum: [\n    '000\u03c90',  # basis mapping, indices are abstract labels\n    '011\u03c91',\n    '100\u03c92',\n    '111\u03c93'\n  ]\n  in_nodes: [0,1]\n  out_nodes: [4]\n  anc_detectors: [2,3]\n  # Any required \u201clookup table\u201d for detector patterns \u2192 bin index is part of the post\u2010processing.\n\nVisual Layout:\n  S1 \u2192 (0,2_pol)  \n               \u2198 \n                 \u25b6\u2500[4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics joint\u2010measurement block at C]\u2500\u2197\u2500 heralded detectors (2,3)\n               \u2197  \n  S2 \u2192 (1,3_pol)  \n\n  Post-selected on one of 4 click-patterns at detectors 2&3, output mode 4 emerges in one of the four frequency bins \u03c9\u2080\u2026\u03c9\u2083.\n\nThis network realizes a nontrivial conversion: it \u201cstrongly couples\u201d two polarization qubits (matter\u2010like excitations) into one THz\u2010spaced frequency\u2010bin photon (light\u2010like output). It can be generalized by:\n  \u2013 Increasing input qubit counts (e.g. three qubits \u2192 one 8\u2010bin frequency octit).\n  \u2013 Swapping chains of such funnels to build high\u2010throughput THz-bandwidth quantum routers.\n  \u2013 Emulating multi-exciton polaritonic networks in an all\u2010linear\u2010optics framework.\n\nThe Expert can use Pytheus to discover the exact beam-splitter and phase settings realizing the 4\u00d74 joint\u2010measurement block."

{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Catalytic Entanglement Amplification of Bell Pairs via a Squeezed-Reservoir Ancilla in Pure LOQC\n\nAbstract: We present a static LOQC circuit that catalytically amplifies the entanglement of two weak Bell pairs in modes (A,B) and (C,D) using a non-maximally entangled squeezed-reservoir ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082). By mixing modes {B,R\u2081} and {C,R\u2082} on two beam splitters and post-selecting on a fixed two-click photon-number pattern at detectors on B and C, the protocol realizes the target transformation in which modes A and D emerge in a stronger Bell-like state |00\u27e9+K(\u03b1,r)|11\u27e9 while the squeezed ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082) is returned unchanged.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a single-shot four-body stabilizer readout for the smallest toric-code plaquette by Bell-entangling each of four data photons with an ancilla photon and sending all ancilla modes through a 4\u00d74 passive interferometer equipped with number-resolving detectors. Heralded two-photon click patterns in even or odd detector pairs directly project the data qubits onto the \u00b11 eigenstates of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084, realizing a direct stabilizer measurement without any feed-forward or dynamic control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photon-Blockade-Assisted Entanglement Purification of Noisy Bell Pairs\n\nAbstract: We introduce a static linear-optical protocol that combines two probabilistic noisy Bell-pair sources with single-emitter photon-blockade nodes to suppress double-pair emissions and distill the target high-fidelity Bell state |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9=(|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9)/\u221a2. By performing a parity check on one photon from each pair via a 50:50 beam splitter and enforcing \u22641-photon inputs through photon-blockade ancillae, specific heralding detection patterns project the remaining photons onto the purified Bell state within the PyTheus framework.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Telecom-Band Frequency-Bin Teleportation MUX for Qubit\u2192Ququart Isometry\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a fully passive, measurement-assisted linear-optical circuit that fuses two qubits, each encoded in a Kerr microcomb\u2019s telecom-band frequency bins, into a single ququart channel via teleportation.  Using two probabilistic Bell-pair photon sources, ancilla modes, a static interferometer and photon-number-resolving detectors, the heralded Choistate  \n\u2211_{i,j\u2208{0,1}} |i,j\u27e9_in |2i+j\u27e9_out  \nrealizes the isometry mapping |00\u27e9\u2192|0\u27e9, |01\u27e9\u2192|1\u27e9, |10\u27e9\u2192|2\u27e9 and |11\u27e9\u2192|3\u27e9 without dynamic feed-forward or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Ancilla-Controlled Programmable Coherent Bell Analyzer\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and simulate a fully coherent measurement supermap\u2014targeting programmable photonic quantum processors\u2014that employs a single Purcell-enhanced on-demand emitter as ancilla (mode 2) to coherently choose between Z- and X-basis Bell measurements on two SPDC-generated photons (modes 0 & 1) within a static linear-optical network. By employing ancilla Bell-pair sources, number-resolving detectors, and a classical optimizer to adjust beam-splitter reflectivities and post-processing coefficients, our variational algorithm approximates the genuine tripartite entanglement measure purely from click statistics.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \n2\u00d72 Entanglement Percolation Network for Semi-Quantum Key Distribution  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe target the implementation of a 2\u00d72 quantum percolation network for semi-quantum key distribution (SQKD) in a purely linear-optical, P\u2006ytheus-compatible setup. Four probabilistic photon-pair sources sit on the grid\u2019s edges and feed two static Bell analyzers at the diagonal midpoints whose heralded outcomes percolate entanglement across opposite corner nodes; the classical corners then perform only reflection or Z-basis measurement to extract correlated raw key bits.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Topologically Protected On-Demand Entanglement Switch in an SSH-Star Nanofiber Network\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a star-shaped quantum switch composed of N identical optical nanofiber SSH chains that meet at a single topological defect, whose zero-energy hub modes are mixed in a programmable multiport beam-splitter to route entanglement. By injecting probabilistic Bell-pair photons at each branch tip, engineering alternating strong/weak static beam-splitter couplings, and performing a heralded Bell measurement on any two chosen hub modes, the device projects the corresponding edge photons into the target two-qubit Bell state on-demand, all realized within PythEus\u2019s linear-optics optimization framework.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a heralded linear-optical protocol that entangles two remote static phase shifts \u03c6_A and \u03c6_B via an ancilla-assisted CPHASE gate, imprinting the nonlinear product cos\u2009\u03c6_A\u00b7cos\u2009\u03c6_B into the conditioned joint click probability. By calibrating and subtracting the individual cos\u2009\u03c6_A and cos\u2009\u03c6_B fringes, the scheme isolates the target phase product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B and attains near-Heisenberg scaling in Fisher information with full loss tolerance.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. The resulting asymmetric coincidence fringe at A\u2013C reproduces the characteristic Fano line shape of a micro-ring resonator in a purely linear, static network\u2014implementable in Pythueus using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, abstract phase shifters, Bell measurements, and photon-number-resolving detectors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  Integrated Photonic Demonstration of a Double-Controlled Four-Way Entanglement Router\n\nAbstract:  We implement on a monolithic photonic chip a Double-Controlled Four-Way Entanglement Router that uses two orthogonally polarized control qubits to coherently select and herald one of four SPDC-based Bell-swap branches in superposition. Conditioned on four ancilla heralding clicks, the qubit returns to its original spatial mode with a relative phase shift exactly equal to the target Zak phase of the SSH band, which is then read out by a simple two-mode interferometer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nDirect Single-Shot Measurement of the Second R\u00e9nyi OTOC in a Four-Site Atom Array via Photonic Interferometry  \n\nAbstract:  \nWe propose a fully linear-optical protocol to measure the second R\u00e9nyi out-of-time-ordered correlator O\u2082(t)=\u27e8W\u2081(t)V\u2084W\u2081(t)V\u2084\u27e9 on a four-qubit atom array in a single shot. The outcome determines which of the four frequency bins \u03c9_k at mode 4 carries the combined label (2i+j).\n  4) Conditioned on the heralded detection at C, photon 4 emerges in the target ququart state |\u03c9_{2i + j}\u27e9\u2084, faithfully representing the original two\u2010qubit state.\n\nAbstract Target Quantum:\n We define a four\u2010mode computational basis for modes 0,1,4:\n   { |0\u20800\u2081\u03c9\u2080\u2084>, |0\u20801\u2081\u03c9\u2081\u2084>, |1\u20800\u2081\u03c9\u2082\u2084>, |1\u20801\u2081\u03c9\u2083\u2084> } \n(with appropriate complex phases set by the joint measurement outcomes).\n The target amplitude list is then the identity map on that basis.\n\nConfig Sketch:\n  num_pre: 2                      # two pair sources\n  num_anc: 0                      # no extra ancillas beyond 4 photons\n  single_emitters: []\n  removed_connections: []         # sources only to their designated pairs\n  loss_func: 'cr'\n  samples: 10\n  target_quantum: [\n    '000\u03c90',  # basis mapping, indices are abstract labels\n    '011\u03c91',\n    '100\u03c92',\n    '111\u03c93'\n  ]\n  in_nodes: [0,1]\n  out_nodes: [4]\n  anc_detectors: [2,3]\n  # Any required \u201clookup table\u201d for detector patterns \u2192 bin index is part of the post\u2010processing.\n\nVisual Layout:\n  S1 \u2192 (0,2_pol)  \n               \u2198 \n                 \u25b6\u2500[4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics joint\u2010measurement block at C]\u2500\u2197\u2500 heralded detectors (2,3)\n               \u2197  \n  S2 \u2192 (1,3_pol)  \n\n  Post-selected on one of 4 click-patterns at detectors 2&3, output mode 4 emerges in one of the four frequency bins \u03c9\u2080\u2026\u03c9\u2083.\n\nThis network realizes a nontrivial conversion: it \u201cstrongly couples\u201d two polarization qubits (matter\u2010like excitations) into one THz\u2010spaced frequency\u2010bin photon (light\u2010like output).     "output": "Thought: This \u201cfunneling\u201d protocol is essentially the same two\u2010qubit\u2192ququart isometry already proposed (e.g. the Telecom\u2010Band Frequency\u2010Bin Teleportation MUX for Qubit\u2192Ququart Isometry in the ensemble), merely swapping polarization and bin encodings.     "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons.     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to weave \u201cthz signal\u201d and \u201cstrong light\u2013matter coupling\u201d into a quantum\u2010network transformation (no raw state generation):\n    a) Heralded \u221aSWAP gate between a polarization qubit and a THz-frequency-bin qubit, realizing a tunable \u201chalf\u2010exchange\u201d (Jaynes\u2013Cummings\u2013style) interaction in linear optics.\n    b) Two\u2010stage repeater: swap a polarization Bell pair into a multi-bin THz link, then back into a polarization Bell pair\u2014demonstrating end-to-end entanglement distribution via a THz \u201cbus.\u201d\n    c) Entanglement \u201cfunneling\u201d of N polarization qubits into one N-bin THz qudit by a single N-photon joint measurement, simulating multi-exciton polariton formation.\n  Step 2: Novelty & Pytheus\u2010obstacles:\n    a) \u221aSWAP is not in the existing lists (we have CNOT, Toffoli, but no \u221aSWAP). It directly simulates \u201cstrong coupling\u201d (half\u2010swap) and mixes DOFs. Pytheus can target arbitrary unitary maps on abstract modes.\n    b) Two\u2010stage swap is a straightforward concatenation of existing ES protocols\u2014less novel.\n    c) N-to-1 funneling is interesting but more complex and may be too large for a first demonstration.\n  Step 3: Choose (a) heralded \u221aSWAP between polarization and THz qubit.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no previous Pytheus example implements the partial\u2010swap gate (\u221aSWAP) between two abstract qubits, especially mixing two different DOFs (polarization \u2194 frequency bins). \u221aSWAP is the quintessential \u201chalf\u2010period\u201d of an exchange (Jaynes\u2013Cummings) coupling, so this directly mimics a strong light\u2013matter interaction in a purely linear-optics network.\n  Step 5: This is feasible in Pytheus because:\n    \u2022 We only need two logical qubits (abstract modes: one 2D polarization, one 2D frequency-bin).\n    \u2022 Target is a well\u2010defined unitary on four basis states\u2014Pytheus can optimize beam\u2010splitter networks + ancillas to realize it heraldedly.\n    \u2022 No cavities or dynamic feedback are required\u2014just probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, detectors.\n    \u2022 It generalizes immediately: higher-dimensional \u221aSWAP, cascaded \u221aSWAP chains, hybrid\u2010DOF quantum routers.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:  \n  Heralded partial\u2010SWAP (\u221aSWAP) gate between a polarization qubit and a THz-frequency-bin qubit, simulating half a Jaynes\u2013Cummings exchange in a pure linear-optics network.\n\nExplanation:  \n  We label four photons/modes as follows:  \n    \u2022 Mode 0 carries a polarization qubit |\u03c8\u27e9_pol to be transformed.  \n    \u2022 Mode 1 carries a frequency-bin qubit in two THz-spaced bins {\u03c9\u2080,\u03c9\u2081}.  \n    \u2022 Modes 2\u20135 are ancillary photons used to herald the gate.  \n\n  Protocol:  \n    1) Prepare two photon\u2010pair sources (S\u2081, S\u2082) that each emit one polarization\u2013polarization Bell pair:  \n       S\u2081\u2192(0,2_pol): |00>+|11>,  S\u2082\u2192(1,3_freq): |\u03c9\u2080\u03c9\u2080>+|\u03c9\u2081\u03c9\u2081>.  \n    2) Introduce four additional ancillary photons (modes 4\u20137) from two more pair sources.  \n    3) Feed modes 0&1 and ancillas 4\u20137 into a 6\u00d76 linear-optics network optimized to implement the 4\u00d74 sub\u2010unitary corresponding to \u221aSWAP in the computational basis {00,01,10,11}:  \n         U_{\u221aSWAP} = diag(1,(1+i)/2,(1+i)/2,1) plus appropriate off-diagonals for the swap half-period.  \n    4) Condition on a specific four-click pattern at detectors on ancilla modes 4\u20137. Upon that herald, the remaining photons exit on modes 2&3 having undergone \u221aSWAP:  \n         |i\u27e9\u2080|j\u27e9\u2081 \u2192 U_{\u221aSWAP}|i\u27e9\u2082|j\u27e9\u2083.  \n\nConfig Sketch (to feed into Pytheus):  \n{  \n  'description': 'Heralded \u221aSWAP gate between polarization qubit and THz frequency-bin qubit.',  \n  'foldername': 'heralded_sqrt_swap_pol2thz',  \n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,  \n  'edges_tried': 30,  \n  'ftol': 1e-06,  \n  'loss_func': 'cr',  \n  'num_pre': 4,          # four pair sources (2 for logical, 2 for ancillas)  \n  'num_anc': 4,          # four ancillary photons to herald  \n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',  \n  'imaginary': False,  \n  'safe_hist': True,  \n  'samples': 20,  \n  'target_quantum': [    # list of 4 output 2-photon bitstrings with \u221aSWAP amplitudes  \n    '00 00 1.0+0.0j',  \n    '01 10 0.5+0.5j',  \n    '10 01 0.5+0.5j',  \n    '11 11 1.0+0.0j'  \n  ],  \n  'in_nodes': [0,1],     # input logical qubits  \n  'out_nodes': [2,3],    # output logical qubits  \n  'anc_detectors': [4,5,6,7],  \n  'single_emitters': [],  \n  'removed_connections': []  \n}  \n\nVisual Layout:  \n   Pair S\u2081: \u2192 modes 0 & 2 (pol)  \n   Pair S\u2082: \u2192 modes 1 & 3 (freq)  \n   Pair S\u2083, S\u2084: \u2192 modes 4\u20137 (ancillas)  \n        \u2502  \n        \u2514\u2500\u2500\u25b6 [6\u00d76 linear\u2010optics network] \u2500\u25b6 Detectors on 4\u20137 (herald)  \n                           \u2502  \n                         Outputs: modes 2,3 carry the \u221aSWAP( mode 0,mode 1 ) result  \n\nGeneralizations:  \n  \u2022 Higher-dimensional \u221aSWAP between pol-THz qudits.  \n  \u2022 Cascaded \u221aSWAP chains to build polariton\u2010like networks.  \n  \u2022 Tunable \u201cswap\u2010angle\u201d gates by re\u2010optimizing the beam\u2010splitter phases to simulate varying coupling strengths.  \n\nThis proposal focuses on a pure network transformation (\u221aSWAP), leverages THz\u2010spaced abstract frequency bins as a second qubit, and directly emulates a half\u2010period of a strong light\u2013matter interaction, all within Pytheus\u2019s linear\u2010optics + heralded\u2010detection framework."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Catalytic Entanglement Amplification of Bell Pairs via a Squeezed-Reservoir Ancilla in Pure LOQC\n\nAbstract: We present a static LOQC circuit that catalytically amplifies the entanglement of two weak Bell pairs in modes (A,B) and (C,D) using a non-maximally entangled squeezed-reservoir ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082). By mixing modes {B,R\u2081} and {C,R\u2082} on two beam splitters and post-selecting on a fixed two-click photon-number pattern at detectors on B and C, the protocol realizes the target transformation in which modes A and D emerge in a stronger Bell-like state |00\u27e9+K(\u03b1,r)|11\u27e9 while the squeezed ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082) is returned unchanged.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a single-shot four-body stabilizer readout for the smallest toric-code plaquette by Bell-entangling each of four data photons with an ancilla photon and sending all ancilla modes through a 4\u00d74 passive interferometer equipped with number-resolving detectors. Heralded two-photon click patterns in even or odd detector pairs directly project the data qubits onto the \u00b11 eigenstates of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084, realizing a direct stabilizer measurement without any feed-forward or dynamic control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photon-Blockade-Assisted Entanglement Purification of Noisy Bell Pairs\n\nAbstract: We introduce a static linear-optical protocol that combines two probabilistic noisy Bell-pair sources with single-emitter photon-blockade nodes to suppress double-pair emissions and distill the target high-fidelity Bell state |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9=(|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9)/\u221a2. By employing ancilla Bell-pair sources, number-resolving detectors, and a classical optimizer to adjust beam-splitter reflectivities and post-processing coefficients, our variational algorithm approximates the genuine tripartite entanglement measure purely from click statistics.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \n2\u00d72 Entanglement Percolation Network for Semi-Quantum Key Distribution  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe target the implementation of a 2\u00d72 quantum percolation network for semi-quantum key distribution (SQKD) in a purely linear-optical, P\u2006ytheus-compatible setup. Four probabilistic photon-pair sources sit on the grid\u2019s edges and feed two static Bell analyzers at the diagonal midpoints whose heralded outcomes percolate entanglement across opposite corner nodes; the classical corners then perform only reflection or Z-basis measurement to extract correlated raw key bits.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Topologically Protected On-Demand Entanglement Switch in an SSH-Star Nanofiber Network\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a star-shaped quantum switch composed of N identical optical nanofiber SSH chains that meet at a single topological defect, whose zero-energy hub modes are mixed in a programmable multiport beam-splitter to route entanglement. By injecting probabilistic Bell-pair photons at each branch tip, engineering alternating strong/weak static beam-splitter couplings, and performing a heralded Bell measurement on any two chosen hub modes, the device projects the corresponding edge photons into the target two-qubit Bell state on-demand, all realized within PythEus\u2019s linear-optics optimization framework.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a heralded linear-optical protocol that entangles two remote static phase shifts \u03c6_A and \u03c6_B via an ancilla-assisted CPHASE gate, imprinting the nonlinear product cos\u2009\u03c6_A\u00b7cos\u2009\u03c6_B into the conditioned joint click probability. By calibrating and subtracting the individual cos\u2009\u03c6_A and cos\u2009\u03c6_B fringes, the scheme isolates the target phase product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B and attains near-Heisenberg scaling in Fisher information with full loss tolerance.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. By performing sequential Bell-state measurements at each intermediate rung, a single-photon qubit is teleported end to end, and the resulting teleportation fidelity as a function of the cross-to-leg coupling ratio unambiguously signals the ladder\u2019s flat-band topological phase transition.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nPhotonic Measurement-Only Linear-Optical Network for Modular S-Matrix Negativity in Non-Abelian Anyon Models\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an explicit linear-optical, measurement-only scheme that simulates the modular S-matrix element S\u208di,j\u208e of a chosen non-Abelian anyon theory via entanglement swapping and heralded Bell\u2013fusion measurements. Post-selected detection of one photon per ancilla and one click at T heralds a U_Z\u2083 phase imprint diag(1,e^{2\u03c0i/3},e^{4\u03c0i/3}) on the teleported qutrit basis {\u22230\u27e9,\u22231\u27e9,\u22232\u27e9}, directly encoding the network\u2019s Z\u2083 loop homology class as a genuine higher-order topological invariant of the teleportation channel.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Bell-State POVM with Two-Mode Squeezed-Vacuum Ancillas\n\nMini-Abstract: We design a near-deterministic Bell-state analyzer by interfacing an unknown two-photon Bell state with two two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla pairs, a fully parameterized 6\u00d76 linear-optical interferometer, and threshold detectors, then use a classical variational optimizer to tune beam-splitter ratios and phase shifts. The target is the four-outcome POVM specified by the Bell basis {\u2502\u03a6\u207a\u27e9,\u2502\u03a6\u207b\u27e9,\u2502\u03a8\u207a\u27e9,\u2502\u03a8\u207b\u27e9}, and our algorithm maximizes the conditional probability of correctly identifying each Bell state beyond the 50% bound of passive optics.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Testing Non-Commutativity of Dissipative Lindblad Channels via Entanglement Swapping\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static, purely linear-optical network using two SPDC Bell-pair sources, amplitude- and phase-damping beam-splitter ancillas, and a post-selected Bell-state measurement to swap entanglement through the two Lindblad maps L\u2081 (amplitude damping) and L\u2082 (phase damping) in both orders. By heralding the \u03a6\u207a outcome and comparing A\u2013D output fidelities under L\u2081\u2218L\u2082 versus L\u2082\u2218L\u2081, we directly quantify the target non-zero commutator [L\u2081,L\u2082], thus probing the non-commutativity of Markovian dissipative channels.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement-Assisted Teleported Error-Detecting Channel (EAQECC-Teleport)\n\nAbstract: We implement a linear-optical network that realizes the target transformation\u2014teleporting a logical qubit from sender A to receiver D while detecting any single-photon erasure\u2014by embedding a (3,1) entanglement-assisted quantum error-detecting code across two relay nodes B and C. Four probabilistic Bell-pair sources and post-selected Bell measurements perform preshared entanglement encoding at A, entanglement swapping at B/C, and decoding at D, heralding both correct qubit transmission and detection of single-photon loss.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Non-Destructive QND Measurement of Photon-Number Difference \u0394N = NA \u2013 ND via Mode-Squeezed Ancillas\n\nMini-Abstract: We introduce a PyTheus network primitive that non-destructively measures the photon-number difference \u0394N = NA \u2013 ND between two distant Fock-encoded modes A and D by mixing each with one arm of a two-mode squeezed ancilla at static beam splitters and post-selecting on the ancilla detector difference outcome k. This scheme infers the target \u0394N without disturbing modes A and D, providing a distributed QND observable extraction for syndrome readout and error checking across network nodes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  Integrated-Photonic Entanglement\u2010Dimension Splitting Supermap via Optical Metasurface  \n\nAbstract:  We propose an on-chip supermap that passively converts a single d\u00b2-dimensional Bell link between nodes A and B into two independent d-dimensional Bell links A\u2013C and B\u2013D, targeting the coherent \u201cdimension splitting\u201d of entanglement without active feed-forward.  The scheme employs two probabilistic photon-pair sources, one ancilla photon, a static (d\u00b2+1)\u00d7(d\u00b2+1) metasurface multiport and number-resolving heralding detectors, and is fully optimizable within the PyTheus framework as a new resource-multiplexing primitive for quantum networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nMeasurement-Based Logical Hadamard via Anyon Braiding in a Toric-Code PEPS Network\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe propose a linear-optics experiment that first projects a 3\u00d73 array of probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources into the Z\u2082 toric-code PEPS ground subspace using four-photon Bell-measurement modules, then injects a single-photon \u201cdata qubit\u201d and teleports it around a nontrivial toric loop by sequential entanglement-swap measurements on boundary edges.  By heralding successful teleportation outcomes, this measurement-driven anyon braiding enacts the logical Hadamard gate (|0\u27e9\u2192|+\u27e9, |1\u27e9\u2192|\u2013\u27e9) on the target qubit, realizing a protected nontrivial quantum logic operation without dynamic feedback or cavity interactions.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. The outcome determines which of the four frequency bins \u03c9_k at mode 4 carries the combined label (2i+j).\n  4) Conditioned on the heralded detection at C, photon 4 emerges in the target ququart state |\u03c9_{2i + j}\u27e9\u2084, faithfully representing the original two\u2010qubit state.\n\nAbstract Target Quantum:\n We define a four\u2010mode computational basis for modes 0,1,4:\n   { |0\u20800\u2081\u03c9\u2080\u2084>, |0\u20801\u2081\u03c9\u2081\u2084>, |1\u20800\u2081\u03c9\u2082\u2084>, |1\u20801\u2081\u03c9\u2083\u2084> } \n(with appropriate complex phases set by the joint measurement outcomes).\n The target amplitude list is then the identity map on that basis.\n\nConfig Sketch:\n  num_pre: 2                      # two pair sources\n  num_anc: 0                      # no extra ancillas beyond 4 photons\n  single_emitters: []\n  removed_connections: []         # sources only to their designated pairs\n  loss_func: 'cr'\n  samples: 10\n  target_quantum: [\n    '000\u03c90',  # basis mapping, indices are abstract labels\n    '011\u03c91',\n    '100\u03c92',\n    '111\u03c93'\n  ]\n  in_nodes: [0,1]\n  out_nodes: [4]\n  anc_detectors: [2,3]\n  # Any required \u201clookup table\u201d for detector patterns \u2192 bin index is part of the post\u2010processing.\n\nVisual Layout:\n  S1 \u2192 (0,2_pol)  \n               \u2198 \n                 \u25b6\u2500[4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics joint\u2010measurement block at C]\u2500\u2197\u2500 heralded detectors (2,3)\n               \u2197  \n  S2 \u2192 (1,3_pol)  \n\n  Post-selected on one of 4 click-patterns at detectors 2&3, output mode 4 emerges in one of the four frequency bins \u03c9\u2080\u2026\u03c9\u2083.\n\nThis network realizes a nontrivial conversion: it \u201cstrongly couples\u201d two polarization qubits (matter\u2010like excitations) into one THz\u2010spaced frequency\u2010bin photon (light\u2010like output).
