By tuning \u03b1 from 0 to \u03c0/2, this gate interpolates between identity (no coupling) and full SWAP, directly simulating varying light\u2013matter coupling strengths at THz energy spacings.\n\nExplanation:\n  Modes:\n    \u2013 Mode 0: polarization qubit |\u03c8\u27e9_pol  \n    \u2013 Mode 1: frequency-bin qubit encoded in two THz-spaced bins {\u03c9\u2080,\u03c9\u2081}  \n    \u2013 Modes 2\u20135: four ancillary photons from two extra pair sources, used for heralding  \n\n  Initial resources (four probabilistic pair sources):\n    S\u2081 \u2192 modes (0,2) in polarization Bell state |00>+|11>  \n    S\u2082 \u2192 modes (1,3) in frequency-bin Bell state |\u03c9\u2080\u03c9\u2080>+|\u03c9\u2081\u03c9\u2081>  \n    S\u2083, S\u2084 \u2192 modes (4,5,6,7) as two more Bell pairs for ancillas  \n\n  Target unitary U_ex(\u03b1) on basis {|00>,|01>,|10>,|11>} of modes (0,1):\n    |00> \u2192 |00>  \n    |11> \u2192 |11>  \n    |01> \u2192  cos\u03b1\u00b7|01> + i\u2009sin\u03b1\u00b7|10>  \n    |10> \u2192  i\u2009sin\u03b1\u00b7|01> + cos\u03b1\u00b7|10>  \n\n  Protocol:\n    1) Inject modes 0\u20131 and ancillas 4\u20137 into a 6\u00d76 linear\u2010optics network optimized to implement the above 4\u00d74 subunitary (parameterized by \u03b1).  \n    2) Condition on a specific four-click pattern at detectors on ancilla modes 4\u20137. Upon herald, modes 2 &3 emerge bearing the U_ex(\u03b1)\u2010transformed logical qubits.  \n\nConfig sketch for Pytheus:\n{\n  'description': 'Heralded parametrized exchange gate U_ex(\u03b1) between polarization and THz frequency qubits.',\n  'foldername': 'tunable_exchange_pol_thz',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_pre': 4,            # This mimics a THz\u2010resonant conditional exchange (strong light\u2013matter coupling) between two polarization excitations.\n\nProtocol Outline:\n  1) Prepare four probabilistic pair sources:\n     S\u2081 \u2192 (0,4): frequency\u2010bin Bell pair |\u03c9\u2080\u03c9\u2080>+|\u03c9\u2081\u03c9\u2081>  \n     S\u2082 \u2192 (1,5): polarization Bell pair |HH>+|VV>  \n     S\u2083,S\u2084 \u2192 (6\u20139): two additional Bell pairs as ancillas  \n  2) Inject modes 0\u20133 (the logical control & targets) and ancillas 6\u20139 into a 7\u00d77 linear\u2010optics circuit optimized by Pytheus to implement the 8\u00d78 Fredkin unitary U_F.  \n  3) Condition on a specific four\u2010click pattern at detectors on ancilla modes 6\u20139. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. On one side, encode a polarization qubit; on the other, encode a qubit into two specific THz\u2010separated frequency modes. Perform a Bell\u2010state measurement that \u201cswaps\u201d the polarization qubit into the frequency\u2010bin DOF, effectively simulating a strong light\u2013matter coupling (polariton) interface between polarization and frequency. Then teleport that qubit onward.\n    b) Hybrid Node Network Emulating THz Strong Coupling via Ancillary High\u2010Dimensional Mode:\n       \u2013 Build a three\u2010node network A\u2013C\u2013B. A\u2013C share a 2D Bell pair, C\u2013B share a D\u2010dimensional Bell pair (D\u226b2), where the extra dimensions emulate matter excitations at THz energy splittings. At C, perform a joint measurement across the 2D and D\u2010dimensional systems (a \u201chybrid\u201d Bell measurement) that enacts an entanglement swap and simulates the strong coupling between light (2D) and matter (D\u2010dimensional THz manifold). This teleports A\u2019s qubit into B\u2019s high\u2010D mode.\n    c) Teleportation of a Qubit through Simulated Polaritonic Modes Using Ancillary THz\u2010Bin Photons:\n       \u2013 Prepare two three\u2010party entangled GHZ\u2010like links: one in polarization and one in THz\u2010frequency bins. Use ancillary THz\u2010frequency photons to mediate a three\u2010photon joint measurement that swaps entanglement between the polarization GHZ and the THz\u2010GHZ, simulating the formation and decay of polaritons under strong coupling. Then use that to teleport a polarization qubit from node A to node B via the THz network.\n  Step 2: Novelty & Obstacles:\n    a) Novel\u2014no prior Pytheus experiment mixes 2D polarization with THz\u2010spaced frequency bins in a swapping protocol. Obstacle: Pytheus requires abstract bins; however frequency bins are just abstract high\u2010dimensional modes, so feasible.\n    b) Novel\u2014hybrid Bell measurement between different dimensions; no direct analog in list. Obstacle: specifying a joint measurement across different subsystems is expressible as target amplitudes.\n    c) More complex\u2014GHZ in two DOFs and GHZ\u2010swap; likely too intricate and may strain Pytheus\u2019s loss\u2010function calibration.\n  Step 3: Pick (a) Frequency\u2010Bin Teleportation;\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it explicitly combines a two\u2010dimensional polarization qubit with a THz\u2010spaced high\u2010dimensional frequency\u2010bin entangled channel in an entanglement\u2010swapping/teleportation protocol. No previous Pytheus target mixes low\u2010D and high\u2010D modes in this manner or references THz spacing.\n  Step 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because:\n    \u2022 It defines an abstract two\u2010mode (polarization) system and an abstract N\u2010mode (frequency bins) system\u2014both allowed.\n    \u2022 The target is an entanglement swapping/teleportation of an abstract qubit, without focusing on physical state generation.\n    \u2022 No feedback control or cavities are needed\u2014only linear optics, probabilistic pair sources, and joint measurements.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription: Teleportation of a polarization qubit into a THz\u2010spaced frequency\u2010bin qudit via entanglement swapping, simulating a strong light\u2013matter coupling interface.\nExplanation:\n  We consider two distinct DOFs:\n    \u2013 Qubit (polarization) at node A.\n    \u2013 Qubit encoded into two THz\u2010separated frequency bins at node B.\n  We start with:\n    1) A polarization Bell pair between A (photon 0) and C (photon 1): |00>_pol + |11>_pol.\n    2) A 2\u2010bin frequency\u2010bin Bell pair between C (photon 2) and B (photon 3): |\u03c91,\u03c91> + |\u03c92,\u03c92>, where \u0394\u03c9 \u2248 THz.\n  Goal: teleport an arbitrary polarization state |\u03c8> on photon 0 to the two\u2010bin frequency qubit on detector 3.\n  Protocol:\n    \u2013 Alice (node A) holds photon 0 in unknown polarization |\u03c8>.\n    \u2013 Charlie at node C holds photons 1 and 2 (one in polarization, one in frequency bins).\n    \u2013 Charlie performs a joint Bell\u2010state measurement between photons 0 and 1 across polarization modes. No existing Pytheus target implements an isometry from two independently held qubits into one higher\u2010dimensional mode in this way.\n  Step 5: This idea is feasible in Pytheus because:\n    \u2022 All modes (polarization qubits and abstract THz\u2010frequency bins) are described purely abstractly.\n    \u2022 The target is a transformation (isometry) between modes, not state generation.\n    \u2022 It uses only probabilistic pair\u2010sources, linear optics, and joint measurements\u2014Pytheus\u2019s supported primitives.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription: Entanglement \u201cfunneling\u201d of two polarization qubits into one THz\u2010frequency qudit via a single joint swap measurement.\n\nExplanation:\n We label modes as follows:\n  \u2013 Node A holds photon 0 in polarization (qubit A).\n  \u2013 Node B holds photon 1 in polarization (qubit B).\n  \u2013 Node C holds photons 2&3: photon 2 is entangled in polarization with A, photon 3 entangled in polarization with B. These come from two independent Bell\u2010pair sources S1 (modes 0&2) and S2 (modes 1&3).\n  \u2013 Node D will output a single photon 4 encoded into four abstract frequency bins {\u03c90,\u03c91,\u03c92,\u03c93} with bin spacing \u0394\u03c9 \u2248 THz, i.e. a ququart.\n\nGoal: implement the isometry\n  |i\u27e9\u2080|j\u27e9\u2081 \u2192 |\u03c9_{2i + j}\u27e9\u2084   for i,j \u2208 {0,1},\nso that the joint polarization state of A&B is coherently \u201cfunnelled\u201d into one higher\u2010dimensional THz mode at D.\n\nProtocol (entanglement\u2010swap style):\n  1) Prepare S1: a polarization Bell pair on modes 0 & 2: |00>+|11>.\n  2) Prepare S2: a polarization Bell pair on modes 1 & 3: |00>+|11>.\n  3) At node C, interfere photons 2&3 in a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics network engineered to implement a joint measurement whose successful heralding projects those two photons onto one of four predefined two\u2010qubit Bell\u2010like basis states. The outcome determines which of the four frequency bins \u03c9_k at mode 4 carries the combined label (2i+j).\n  4) Conditioned on the heralded detection at C, photon 4 emerges in the target ququart state |\u03c9_{2i + j}\u27e9\u2084, faithfully representing the original two\u2010qubit state.\n\nAbstract Target Quantum:\n We define a four\u2010mode computational basis for modes 0,1,4:\n   { |0\u20800\u2081\u03c9\u2080\u2084>, |0\u20801\u2081\u03c9\u2081\u2084>, |1\u20800\u2081\u03c9\u2082\u2084>, |1\u20801\u2081\u03c9\u2083\u2084> } \n(with appropriate complex phases set by the joint measurement outcomes).\n The target amplitude list is then the identity map on that basis.\n\nConfig Sketch:\n  num_pre: 2                      # two pair sources\n  num_anc: 0                      # no extra ancillas beyond 4 photons\n  single_emitters: []\n  removed_connections: []         # sources only to their designated pairs\n  loss_func: 'cr'\n  samples: 10\n  target_quantum: [\n    '000\u03c90',  # basis mapping, indices are abstract labels\n    '011\u03c91',\n    '100\u03c92',\n    '111\u03c93'\n  ]\n  in_nodes: [0,1]\n  out_nodes: [4]\n  anc_detectors: [2,3]\n  # Any required \u201clookup table\u201d for detector patterns \u2192 bin index is part of the post\u2010processing.\n\nVisual Layout:\n  S1 \u2192 (0,2_pol)  \n               \u2198 \n                 \u25b6\u2500[4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics joint\u2010measurement block at C]\u2500\u2197\u2500 heralded detectors (2,3)\n               \u2197  \n  S2 \u2192 (1,3_pol)  \n\n  Post-selected on one of 4 click-patterns at detectors 2&3, output mode 4 emerges in one of the four frequency bins \u03c9\u2080\u2026\u03c9\u2083.\n\nThis network realizes a nontrivial conversion: it \u201cstrongly couples\u201d two polarization qubits (matter\u2010like excitations) into one THz\u2010spaced frequency\u2010bin photon (light\u2010like output). It can be generalized by:\n  \u2013 Increasing input qubit counts (e.g. three qubits \u2192 one 8\u2010bin frequency octit).\n  \u2013 Swapping chains of such funnels to build high\u2010throughput THz-bandwidth quantum routers.\n  \u2013 Emulating multi-exciton polaritonic networks in an all\u2010linear\u2010optics framework.\n\nThe Expert can use Pytheus to discover the exact beam-splitter and phase settings realizing the 4\u00d74 joint\u2010measurement block.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The protocol duplicates the known two\u2010qubit to four\u2010level frequency\u2010bin mapping via a single joint measurement and adds only a change of DOF. It directly simulates \u201cstrong coupling\u201d (half\u2010swap) and mixes DOFs. Pytheus can target arbitrary unitary maps on abstract modes.\n    b) Two\u2010stage swap is a straightforward concatenation of existing ES protocols\u2014less novel.\n    c) N-to-1 funneling is interesting but more complex and may be too large for a first demonstration.\n  Step 3: Choose (a) heralded \u221aSWAP between polarization and THz qubit.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no previous Pytheus example implements the partial\u2010swap gate (\u221aSWAP) between two abstract qubits, especially mixing two different DOFs (polarization \u2194 frequency bins). \u221aSWAP is the quintessential \u201chalf\u2010period\u201d of an exchange (Jaynes\u2013Cummings) coupling, so this directly mimics a strong light\u2013matter interaction in a purely linear-optics network.\n  Step 5: This is feasible in Pytheus because:\n    \u2022 We only need two logical qubits (abstract modes: one 2D polarization, one 2D frequency-bin).\n    \u2022 Target is a well\u2010defined unitary on four basis states\u2014Pytheus can optimize beam\u2010splitter networks + ancillas to realize it heraldedly.\n    \u2022 No cavities or dynamic feedback are required\u2014just probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, detectors.\n    \u2022 It generalizes immediately: higher-dimensional \u221aSWAP, cascaded \u221aSWAP chains, hybrid\u2010DOF quantum routers.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:  \n  Heralded partial\u2010SWAP (\u221aSWAP) gate between a polarization qubit and a THz-frequency-bin qubit, simulating half a Jaynes\u2013Cummings exchange in a pure photon\u2010pair sources (S\u2081, S\u2082) that each emit one polarization\u2013polarization Bell pair:  \n       S\u2081\u2192(0,2_pol): |00>+|11>,  S\u2082\u2192(1,3_freq): |\u03c9\u2080\u03c9\u2080>+|\u03c9\u2081\u03c9\u2081>.  \n    2) Introduce four additional ancillary photons (modes 4\u20137) from two more pair sources.  \n    3) Feed modes 0&1 and ancillas 4\u20137 into a 6\u00d76 linear-optics network optimized to implement the 4\u00d74 sub\u2010unitary corresponding to \u221aSWAP in the computational basis {00,01,10,11}:  \n         U_{\u221aSWAP} = diag(1,(1+i)/2,(1+i)/2,1) plus appropriate off-diagonals for the swap half-period.  \n    4) Condition on a specific four-click pattern at detectors on ancilla modes 4\u20137. Upon that herald, the remaining photons exit on modes 2&3 having undergone \u221aSWAP:  \n         |i\u27e9\u2080|j\u27e9\u2081 \u2192 U_{\u221aSWAP}|i\u27e9\u2082|j\u27e9\u2083.  \n\nConfig Sketch (to feed into Pytheus):  \n{  \n  'description': 'Heralded \u221aSWAP gate between polarization qubit and THz frequency-bin qubit.',  \n  'foldername': 'heralded_sqrt_swap_pol2thz',  \n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,  \n  'edges_tried': 30,  \n  'ftol': 1e-06,  \n  'loss_func': 'cr',  \n  'num_pre': 4,          # four pair sources (2 for logical, 2 for ancillas)  \n  'num_anc': 4,          # four ancillary photons to herald  \n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',  \n  'imaginary': False,  \n  'safe_hist': True,  \n  'samples': 20,  \n  'target_quantum': [    # list of 4 output 2-photon bitstrings with \u221aSWAP amplitudes  \n    '00 00 1.0+0.0j',  \n    '01 10 0.5+0.5j',  \n    '10 01 0.5+0.5j',  \n    '11 11 1.0+0.0j'  \n  ],  \n  'in_nodes': [0,1],     # input logical qubits  \n  'out_nodes': [2,3],    # output logical qubits  \n  'anc_detectors': [4,5,6,7],  \n  'single_emitters': [],  \n  'removed_connections': []  \n}  \n\nVisual Layout:  \n   Pair S\u2081: \u2192 modes 0 & 2 (pol)  \n   Pair S\u2082: \u2192 modes 1 & 3 (freq)  \n   Pair S\u2083, S\u2084: \u2192 modes 4\u20137 (ancillas)  \n        \u2502  \n        \u2514\u2500\u2500\u25b6 [6\u00d76 linear\u2010optics network] \u2500\u25b6 Detectors on 4\u20137 (herald)  \n                           \u2502  \n                         Outputs: modes 2,3 carry the \u221aSWAP( mode 0,mode 1 ) result  \n\nGeneralizations:  \n  \u2022 Higher-dimensional \u221aSWAP between pol-THz qudits.  \n  \u2022 Cascaded \u221aSWAP chains to build polariton\u2010like networks.  \n  \u2022 Tunable \u201cswap\u2010angle\u201d gates by re\u2010optimizing the beam\u2010splitter phases to simulate varying coupling strengths.  \n\nThis proposal focuses on a pure network transformation (\u221aSWAP), leverages THz\u2010spaced abstract frequency bins as a second qubit, and directly emulates a half\u2010period of a strong light\u2013matter interaction, all within Pytheus\u2019s linear\u2010optics + heralded\u2010detection framework.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is essentially the same heralded \u221aSWAP gate previously suggested. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. Refine it and aim for producing a truly novel idea.\n\nHere are the targets that pytheus has already designed quantum optics experiments for.  A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. interesting but more complex and may be too large for a first demonstration.\n  Step 3: Choose (a) heralded \u221aSWAP between polarization and THz qubit.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no previous Pytheus example implements the partial\u2010swap gate (\u221aSWAP) between two abstract qubits, especially mixing two different DOFs (polarization \u2194 frequency bins). \u221aSWAP is the quintessential \u201chalf\u2010period\u201d of an exchange (Jaynes\u2013Cummings) coupling, so this directly mimics a strong light\u2013matter interaction in a purely linear-optics network.\n  Step 5: This is feasible in Pytheus because:\n    \u2022 We only need two logical qubits (abstract modes: one 2D polarization, one 2D frequency-bin).\n    \u2022 Target is a well\u2010defined unitary on four basis states\u2014Pytheus can optimize beam\u2010splitter networks + ancillas to realize it heraldedly.\n    \u2022 No cavities or dynamic feedback are required\u2014just probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, detectors.\n    \u2022 It generalizes immediately: higher-dimensional \u221aSWAP, cascaded \u221aSWAP chains, hybrid\u2010DOF quantum routers.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:  \n  Heralded partial\u2010SWAP (\u221aSWAP) gate between a polarization qubit and a THz-frequency-bin qubit, simulating half a Jaynes\u2013Cummings exchange in a pure linear-optics network.\n\nExplanation:  \n  We label four photons/modes as follows:  \n    \u2022 Mode 0 carries a polarization qubit |\u03c8\u27e9_pol to be transformed.  \n    \u2022 Mode 1 carries a frequency-bin qubit in two THz-spaced bins {\u03c9\u2080,\u03c9\u2081}.  \n    \u2022 Modes 2\u20135 are ancillary photons used to herald the gate.  \n\n  Protocol:  \n    1) Prepare two photon\u2010pair sources (S\u2081, S\u2082) that each emit one polarization\u2013polarization Bell pair:  \n       S\u2081\u2192(0,2_pol): |00>+|11>,  S\u2082\u2192(1,3_freq): |\u03c9\u2080\u03c9\u2080>+|\u03c9\u2081\u03c9\u2081>.  \n    2) Introduce four additional ancillary photons (modes 4\u20137) from two more pair sources.  \n    3) Feed modes 0&1 and ancillas 4\u20137 into a 6\u00d76 linear-optics network optimized to implement the 4\u00d74 sub\u2010unitary corresponding to \u221aSWAP in the computational basis {00,01,10,11}:  \n         U_{\u221aSWAP} = diag(1,(1+i)/2,(1+i)/2,1) plus appropriate off-diagonals for the swap half-period.  \n    4) Condition on a specific four-click pattern at detectors on ancilla modes 4\u20137. Upon that herald, the remaining photons exit on modes 2&3 having undergone \u221aSWAP:  \n         |i\u27e9\u2080|j\u27e9\u2081 \u2192 U_{\u221aSWAP}|i\u27e9\u2082|j\u27e9\u2083.  \n\nConfig Sketch (to feed into Pytheus):  \n{  \n  'description': 'Heralded \u221aSWAP gate between polarization qubit and THz frequency-bin qubit.',  \n  'foldername': 'heralded_sqrt_swap_pol2thz',  \n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,  \n  'edges_tried': 30,  \n  'ftol': 1e-06,  \n  'loss_func': 'cr',  \n  'num_pre': 4,          # This builds directly on entanglement swapping/teleportation but adds a control qubit in a different DOF (THz bins), producing a genuine new network transformation not in Pytheus\u2019s existing library.\n  Step 2: This is novel because no prior Pytheus design implements a controlled teleportation or \u201cquantum switch\u201d between arbitrary nodes, especially where the control is encoded in a THz-frequency qubit and the signal is polarization. \n  Step 3: It is feasible in Pytheus because it only uses four probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, joint measurements, and heralding detectors\u2014no cavities or feedback\u2014exactly Pytheus\u2019s supported primitives. We define an 8\u00d78 target unitary mapping for the three logical qubits (control + signal + two \u201cblank\u201d Bell outputs) and four ancillas.\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  Heralded Quantum Router via THz-Controlled Entanglement Swapping.\n  We have three logical qubits:\n    \u2022 Control qubit c encoded in two THz-separated frequency bins on mode 0.\n    \u2022 Signal qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 encoded in polarization on mode 1.\n    \u2022 Two \u201cdestination\u201d qubits B and D initially in blank states (each half of a Bell resource).\n  Resources (four probabilistic pair sources):\n    S\u2081 \u2192 (mode 1,2) creates the signal\u2013bus Bell pair in polarization: |HH>+|VV>.\n    S\u2082 \u2192 (mode 3,4) creates a Bell pair destined for node B in polarization.\n    S\u2083 \u2192 (mode 5,6) creates a Bell pair destined for node D in polarization.\n    S\u2084 \u2192 (mode 0,7) creates the control\u2013ancilla Bell pair in frequency bins: |\u03c9\u2080\u03c9\u2080>+|\u03c9\u2081\u03c9\u2081>, \u0394\u03c9\u2248THz.\n  Ancilla photons on modes 2,4,6,7 are measured by a central router (Charlie) in one joint multi-photon projection.\n  Protocol:\n    \u2022 Charlie mixes modes {0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7} in a tailored 8\u00d78 linear-optics network and conditions on a specific four-click heralding pattern on ancilla detectors at modes {2,4,6,7}.\n    \u2022 Upon that herald, the control qubit exits on mode 0\u2032 (unchanged), and the signal qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 is teleported to either node B (mode 3\u2032) if c=\u03c9\u2080 or to node D (mode 5\u2032) if c=\u03c9\u2081.\n    \u2022 If c=\u03c9\u2080, the Bell pair S\u2082 is consumed and B receives |\u03c8\u27e9; if c=\u03c9\u2081, B receives the blank partner of S\u2082 (|0\u27e9) and D receives |\u03c8\u27e9.\n  Abstract Target Quantum (input\u2192output labels; 3 logical qubits c,s,t plus 4 ancillas a):\n    We label basis states as |c s b d ;\u2009a2 a4 a6 a7\u27e9\u208din\u208e \u2192 |c ;\u2009b\u2032 d\u2032\u27e9\u208dout\u208e \u2297 |herald\u27e9,\n    with the mapping:\n      for c=0 (\u03c9\u2080): |0,s,0,0;0000\u27e9\u2192|0;b=s,d=0\u27e9  \n      for c=1 (\u03c9\u2081): |1,s,0,0;0000\u27e9\u2192|1;b=0,d=s\u27e9  \n    (All off-diagonal amplitudes zero, phases chosen real.)\nPytheus Config Sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Heralded quantum router: control in THz bins, signal in polarization, routes to B or D.',\n  'foldername': 'thz_controlled_router',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 50,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_pre': 4,                 # four Bell-pair sources\n  'num_anc': 4,                 # four ancilla photons (modes 2,4,6,7)\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 20,\n  'target_quantum': [\n    '00000000 0  s 0 0',  # c=0,s, b\u2032=s,d\u2032=0\n    '10000000 1 0 0 s'    # c=1,s, b\u2032=0,d\u2032=s\n  ],\n  'in_nodes': [0,1,3,5],        # control(0), signal(1), B-input(3), D-input(5)\n  'out_nodes': [0,3,5],         # control(0), B-out(3), D-out(5)\n  'anc_detectors': [2,4,6,7],   # modes to herald\n  'single_emitters': [],\n  'removed_connections': []\n}\nVisual Layout:\n  S\u2081 \u2192 modes 1&2 (pol)\n  S\u2082 \u2192 modes 3&4 (pol)\n  S\u2083 \u2192 modes 5&6 (pol)\n  S\u2084 \u2192 modes 0&7 (freq)\n           \u2502\n           \u2514\u2500\u25b6 [8\u00d78 linear-optics router network at Charlie] \u2500\u25b6 Detectors on {2,4,6,7}\n                       \u2502\n                  Outputs: control\u2192mode0; B\u2192mode3; D\u2192mode5\nGeneralizations:\n  \u2022 Extend control to an N-bin THz qudit for routing among N destinations.  \n  \u2022 Cascade routers to build THz-mediated entanglement percolation in large networks.  \n  \u2022 Vary the control qudit dimension to emulate multi-level polaritonic switching.\nThis device realizes a fully heralded, controlled-swap/teleportation primitive\u2014a genuine new quantum-network building block mixing THz and polarization DOFs\u2014fully synthesizable in Pytheus."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Catalytic Entanglement Amplification of Bell Pairs via a Squeezed-Reservoir Ancilla in Pure LOQC\n\nAbstract: We present a static LOQC circuit that catalytically amplifies the entanglement of two weak Bell pairs in modes (A,B) and (C,D) using a non-maximally entangled squeezed-reservoir ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082). By mixing modes {B,R\u2081} and {C,R\u2082} on two beam splitters and post-selecting on a fixed two-click photon-number pattern at detectors on B and C, the protocol realizes the target transformation in which modes A and D emerge in a stronger Bell-like state |00\u27e9+K(\u03b1,r)|11\u27e9 while the squeezed ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082) is returned unchanged.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a single-shot four-body stabilizer readout for the smallest toric-code plaquette by Bell-entangling each of four data photons with an ancilla photon and sending all ancilla modes through a 4\u00d74 passive interferometer equipped with number-resolving detectors. Heralded two-photon click patterns in even or odd detector pairs directly project the data qubits onto the \u00b11 eigenstates of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084, realizing a direct stabilizer measurement without any feed-forward or dynamic control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photon-Blockade-Assisted Entanglement Purification of Noisy Bell Pairs\n\nAbstract: We introduce a static linear-optical protocol that combines two probabilistic noisy Bell-pair sources with single-emitter photon-blockade nodes to suppress double-pair emissions and distill the target high-fidelity Bell state |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9=(|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9)/\u221a2. Using two probabilistic Bell-pair photon sources, ancilla modes, a static interferometer and photon-number-resolving detectors, the heralded Choistate  \n\u2211_{i,j\u2208{0,1}} |i,j\u27e9_in |2i+j\u27e9_out  \nrealizes the isometry mapping |00\u27e9\u2192|0\u27e9, |01\u27e9\u2192|1\u27e9, |10\u27e9\u2192|2\u27e9 and |11\u27e9\u2192|3\u27e9 without dynamic feed-forward or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Ancilla-Controlled Programmable Coherent Bell Analyzer\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and simulate a fully coherent measurement supermap\u2014targeting programmable photonic quantum processors\u2014that employs a single Purcell-enhanced on-demand emitter as ancilla (mode 2) to coherently choose between Z- and X-basis Bell measurements on two SPDC-generated photons (modes 0 & 1) within a static linear-optical network. Four probabilistic photon-pair sources sit on the grid\u2019s edges and feed two static Bell analyzers at the diagonal midpoints whose heralded outcomes percolate entanglement across opposite corner nodes; the classical corners then perform only reflection or Z-basis measurement to extract correlated raw key bits.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Topologically Protected On-Demand Entanglement Switch in an SSH-Star Nanofiber Network\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a star-shaped quantum switch composed of N identical optical nanofiber SSH chains that meet at a single topological defect, whose zero-energy hub modes are mixed in a programmable multiport beam-splitter to route entanglement. By calibrating and subtracting the individual cos\u2009\u03c6_A and cos\u2009\u03c6_B fringes, the scheme isolates the target phase product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B and attains near-Heisenberg scaling in Fisher information with full loss tolerance.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By encoding the occupancies of sites i,j,k,l into four single-photon emitters and post-selecting two designated click patterns corresponding to the target logical states |0011\u27e9 and |1100\u27e9 (heralding projections onto the even \u201c+1\u201d and odd \u201c\u22121\u201d correlator subspaces), we directly read out G^(4) without the need for local spin rotations or tomography.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ancilla-Assisted Linear-Optical Two-Qutrit SWAP-Test for Symmetric vs. Antisymmetric Projections\n\nAbstract: We present a heralded linear-optical network that implements the two-qutrit SWAP-test (symmetric vs. antisymmetric projector) as a primitive for second R\u00e9nyi-entropy measurement on two collective-spin modes converted into photonic qutrits via spin\u2013orbit torque transduction. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced.     "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. Perform a Bell\u2010state measurement that \u201cswaps\u201d the polarization qubit into the frequency\u2010bin DOF, effectively simulating a strong light\u2013matter coupling (polariton) interface between polarization and frequency. Then teleport that qubit onward.\n    b) Hybrid Node Network Emulating THz Strong Coupling via Ancillary High\u2010Dimensional Mode:\n       \u2013 Build a three\u2010node network A\u2013C\u2013B. A\u2013C share a 2D Bell pair, C\u2013B share a D\u2010dimensional Bell pair (D\u226b2), where the extra dimensions emulate matter excitations at THz energy splittings. No existing Pytheus target implements an isometry from two independently held qubits into one higher\u2010dimensional mode in this way.\n  Step 5: This idea is feasible in Pytheus because:\n    \u2022 All modes (polarization qubits and abstract THz\u2010frequency bins) are described purely abstractly.\n    \u2022 The target is a transformation (isometry) between modes, not state generation.\n    \u2022 It uses only probabilistic pair\u2010sources, linear optics, and joint measurements\u2014Pytheus\u2019s supported primitives.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription: Entanglement \u201cfunneling\u201d of two polarization qubits into one THz\u2010frequency qudit via a single joint swap measurement.\n\nExplanation:\n We label modes as follows:\n  \u2013 Node A holds photon 0 in polarization (qubit A).\n  \u2013 Node B holds photon 1 in polarization (qubit B).\n  \u2013 Node C holds photons 2&3: photon 2 is entangled in polarization with A, photon 3 entangled in polarization with B. These come from two independent Bell\u2010pair sources S1 (modes 0&2) and S2 (modes 1&3).\n  \u2013 Node D will output a single photon 4 encoded into four abstract frequency bins {\u03c90,\u03c91,\u03c92,\u03c93} with bin spacing \u0394\u03c9 \u2248 THz, i.e. a ququart.\n\nGoal: implement the isometry\n  |i\u27e9\u2080|j\u27e9\u2081 \u2192 |\u03c9_{2i + j}\u27e9\u2084   for i,j \u2208 {0,1},\nso that the joint polarization state of A&B is coherently \u201cfunnelled\u201d into one higher\u2010dimensional THz mode at D.\n\nProtocol (entanglement\u2010swap style):\n  1) Prepare S1: a polarization Bell pair on modes 0 & 2: |00>+|11>.\n  2) Prepare S2: a polarization Bell pair on modes 1 & 3: |00>+|11>.\n  3) At node C, interfere photons 2&3 in a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics network engineered to implement a joint measurement whose successful heralding projects those two photons onto one of four predefined two\u2010qubit Bell\u2010like basis states. The outcome determines which of the four frequency bins \u03c9_k at mode 4 carries the combined label (2i+j).\n  4) Conditioned on the heralded detection at C, photon 4 emerges in the target ququart state |\u03c9_{2i + j}\u27e9\u2084, faithfully representing the original two\u2010qubit state.\n\nAbstract Target Quantum:\n We define a four\u2010mode computational basis for modes 0,1,4:\n   { |0\u20800\u2081\u03c9\u2080\u2084>, |0\u20801\u2081\u03c9\u2081\u2084>, |1\u20800\u2081\u03c9\u2082\u2084>, |1\u20801\u2081\u03c9\u2083\u2084> } \n(with appropriate complex phases set by the joint measurement outcomes).\n The target amplitude list is then the identity map on that basis.\n\nConfig Sketch:\n  num_pre: 2                      # two pair sources\n  num_anc: 0                      # no extra ancillas beyond 4 photons\n  single_emitters: []\n  removed_connections: []         # sources only to their designated pairs\n  loss_func: 'cr'\n  samples: 10\n  target_quantum: [\n    '000\u03c90',  # basis mapping, indices are abstract labels\n    '011\u03c91',\n    '100\u03c92',\n    '111\u03c93'\n  ]\n  in_nodes: [0,1]\n  out_nodes: [4]\n  anc_detectors: [2,3]\n  # Any required \u201clookup table\u201d for detector patterns \u2192 bin index is part of the post\u2010processing.\n\nVisual Layout:\n  S1 \u2192 (0,2_pol)  \n               \u2198 \n                 \u25b6\u2500[4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics joint\u2010measurement block at C]\u2500\u2197\u2500 heralded detectors (2,3)\n               \u2197  \n  S2 \u2192 (1,3_pol)  \n\n  Post-selected on one of 4 click-patterns at detectors 2&3, output mode 4 emerges in one of the four frequency bins \u03c9\u2080\u2026\u03c9\u2083.\n\nThis network realizes a nontrivial conversion: it \u201cstrongly couples\u201d two polarization qubits (matter\u2010like excitations) into one THz\u2010spaced frequency\u2010bin photon (light\u2010like output). It can be generalized by:\n  \u2013 Increasing input qubit counts (e.g. three qubits \u2192 one 8\u2010bin frequency octit).\n  \u2013 Swapping chains of such funnels to build high\u2010throughput THz-bandwidth quantum routers.\n  \u2013 Emulating multi-exciton polaritonic networks in an all\u2010linear\u2010optics framework.\n\nThe Expert can use Pytheus to discover the exact beam-splitter and phase settings realizing the 4\u00d74 joint\u2010measurement block.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The protocol duplicates the known two\u2010qubit to four\u2010level frequency\u2010bin mapping via a single joint measurement and adds only a change of DOF. To be novel, you must introduce a genuinely new entangling measurement, resource conversion, or higher-order network effect not captured by existing qubit\u2192ququart teleportation protocols.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! It directly simulates \u201cstrong coupling\u201d (half\u2010swap) and mixes DOFs. Pytheus can target arbitrary unitary maps on abstract modes.\n    b) Two\u2010stage swap is a straightforward concatenation of existing ES protocols\u2014less novel.\n    c) N-to-1 funneling is interesting but more complex and may be too large for a first demonstration.\n  Step 3: Choose (a) heralded \u221aSWAP between polarization and THz qubit.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no previous Pytheus example implements the partial\u2010swap gate (\u221aSWAP) between two abstract qubits, especially mixing two different DOFs (polarization \u2194 frequency bins). \u221aSWAP is the quintessential \u201chalf\u2010period\u201d of an exchange (Jaynes\u2013Cummings) coupling, so this directly mimics a strong light\u2013matter interaction in a purely linear-optics network.\n  Step 5: This is feasible in Pytheus because:\n    \u2022 We only need two logical qubits (abstract modes: one 2D polarization, one 2D frequency-bin).\n    \u2022 Target is a well\u2010defined unitary on four a frequency-bin qubit in two THz-spaced bins {\u03c9\u2080,\u03c9\u2081}.  \n    \u2022 Modes 2\u20135 are ancillary photons used to herald the gate.  \n\n  Protocol:  \n    1) Prepare two photon\u2010pair sources (S\u2081, S\u2082) that each emit one polarization\u2013polarization Bell pair:  \n       S\u2081\u2192(0,2_pol): |00>+|11>,  S\u2082\u2192(1,3_freq): into a 6\u00d76 linear-optics network optimized to implement the 4\u00d74 sub\u2010unitary corresponding to \u221aSWAP in the computational basis {00,01,10,11}:  \n         U_{\u221aSWAP} = diag(1,(1+i)/2,(1+i)/2,1) plus appropriate off-diagonals for the swap half-period.  \n    4) Condition on a specific four-click pattern at detectors on ancilla modes 4\u20137. Upon that herald, the remaining photons exit on modes 2&3 having undergone \u221aSWAP:  \n         |i\u27e9\u2080|j\u27e9\u2081 \u2192 U_{\u221aSWAP}|i\u27e9\u2082|j\u27e9\u2083.  \n\nConfig Sketch (to feed into Pytheus):  \n{  \n  'description': 'Heralded \u221aSWAP gate between polarization qubit and THz frequency-bin qubit.',  \n  'foldername': 'heralded_sqrt_swap_pol2thz',  \n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,  \n  'edges_tried': 30,  \n  'ftol': 1e-06,  \n  'loss_func': 'cr',  \n  'num_pre': 4,          #     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to fuse \u201cthz signal\u201d and \u201cstrong light\u2013matter coupling\u201d into a network transformation (no state generation):\n    a) Frequency\u2010bin\u2013controlled entanglement swapping: use a THz\u2010frequency qudit to program which Bell basis Charlie projects onto when swapping two polarization Bell pairs, thus steering nonlocally the output entangled state between A and B.\n    b) Parametrized exchange gate U_ex(\u03b1) between a polarization qubit and a 2\u2010bin THz qubit (\u221aSWAP family).\n    c) DOF\u2010hybrid Fredkin: control in THz bins, targets in polarization.\n  Step 2: (a) is genuinely new\u2014no prior Pytheus example programs the Bell\u2010measurement basis with a quantum control qudit. The control\u2010gate ideas (b,c) have been attempted and flagged as insufficiently novel.\n  Step 3: Choose (a).\n  Step 4: This is novel because it elevates entanglement\u2010swapping to a programmable, quantum\u2010controlled operation: a THz\u2010frequency\u2010bin qudit at Charlie\u2019s node chooses the measurement basis for the swap, thereby deterministically routing A\u2013B into one of D different Bell\u2010like states. No existing Pytheus experiment features a quantum\u2010controlled Bell\u2010measurement basis.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus:\n    \u2022 Defines two polarization\u2010encoded Bell pairs (A\u2013C, C\u2013B) plus one D\u2010dimensional THz control qudit at C\u2014all abstract modes.\n    \u2022 The target is a measurement\u2010induced network: the joint unitary+projection that maps input modes (two pol. qubits + one freq qudit) to one of D entangled outputs between A and B, correlated with control. This is expressible as a list of basis\u2010state amplitudes.\n    \u2022 Only uses linear optics, probabilistic pair sources, joint measurements, heralding detectors\u2014no cavities or feedback.\n    \u2022 Generalizes to arbitrary D (frequency\u2010multiplexed programmability) and multi\u2010swap chains.\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  Programmable, THz\u2010frequency\u2010bin\u2013controlled entanglement\u2010swap:\n   \u2022 Two polarization\u2010Bell pairs: S\u2081 entangles modes (0_pol,1_pol), S\u2082 entangles (2_pol,3_pol).\n   \u2022 A D\u2010dimensional THz\u2010frequency\u2010bin control qudit lives on mode 4_freq (bins \u03c9\u2080\u2026\u03c9_{D-1}, \u0394\u03c9\u2248THz).\n   \u2022 Charlie holds modes 1_pol,2_pol and 4_freq. He performs a single joint measurement which, controlled by the state |k\u27e9_\u03c9 on mode 4_freq, projects modes (1,2) onto the k-th generalised Bell basis. Upon heralding that measurement, modes 0_pol (Alice) and 3_pol (Bob) become entangled in the corresponding k-th Bell\u2010like state.\n   \u2022 This realizes a quantum\u2010controlled entanglement\u2010swap: the THz qudit programs which entangled state A\u2013B emerge in, all in one measurement step.\n\nAbstract Target Mapping:\n  Input basis: |b\u2080,b\u2081; b\u2082,b\u2083; k\u27e9  where b\u1d62\u2208{0,1} are polarizations on modes 0\u20133, k\u2208{0\u2026D\u22121} is THz bin on mode 4.\n  Output (post\u2010selected) on modes 0&3:\n    |b\u2080,b\u2083\u27e9 \u2192 the k-th Bell basis vector  \n  Control qudit is consumed in the measurement; herald detectors read out k.\n  In amplitude form, for each k we have\n    \u2211_{x,y=0,1}  (\u22121)^{f_k(x,y)} |x\u2080,y\u2083\u27e9\u27e8x\u2081,y\u2082;k\u2084|  \n  where f_k(x,y) encodes the phase pattern of the k-th generalised Bell basis.\n\nPytheus Config Sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Programmable entanglement swapping: THz\u2010freq control qudit selects Bell basis',\n  'foldername': 'thz_controlled_swap',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 50,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_pre': 3,                # two Bell pairs + one control\u2010pair if using a pair source to prepare freq qudit entangled with ancilla\n  'num_anc': 2,                # ancilla photons to herald the joint measurement\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 20,\n  'target_quantum': [          # rough pseudocode for D=4 example\n    # for k=0\u20263, list the 16 two\u2010photon bitstrings with k\u2010dependent phases mapping modes [0,3,1,2,4] to output on [0,3]\n    '00000 1.0+0j', '01110 1.0+0j', ...,  \n    '11111 1.0+0j'\n  ],\n  'in_nodes': [0,1,2,3,4],      # pol input modes 0\u20133, freq control 4\n  'out_nodes': [0,3],          # pol outputs\n  'anc_detectors': [5,6],      # heralding modes\n  'single_emitters': [],\n  'removed_connections': []\n}\n\nVisual Layout:\n  S\u2081 \u2192 modes 0_pol & 1_pol  \n  S\u2082 \u2192 modes 2_pol & 3_pol  \n  S\u2083 \u2192 if needed, prepare freq qudit on mode 4_freq & ancilla\n       \u2502\n       \u2514\u2500\u25b6 [Linear\u2010optics network at Charlie mixing modes 1,2,4 plus ancillas 5,6]\n                 \u2514\u2500\u25b6 detectors on 1,2,4,5,6 (herald k)\n                       \u2502\n                    Outputs: modes 0,3 in the k-th Bell state\n\nGeneralizations:\n  \u2022 Increase D to perform on\u2010the\u2010fly basis programmability over many frequency channels.  \n  \u2022 Cascade controlled\u2010swaps to build quantum\u2010programmable network topologies.  \n  \u2022 Use single\u2010photon emitters to prepare the control qudit, exploring hybrid\u2010source flexibility.\n\nThis network is a new three\u2010party quantum\u2010network primitive: quantum\u2010programmed entanglement swap driven by a THz\u2010frequency\u2010bin control. Pytheus can optimize the exact beamsplitter phases and ancilla couplings needed to realize it in linear optics with photon\u2010counting heralds."
