It directly simulates \u201cstrong coupling\u201d (half\u2010swap) and mixes DOFs. Pytheus can target arbitrary unitary maps on abstract modes.\n    b) Two\u2010stage swap is a straightforward concatenation of existing ES protocols\u2014less novel.\n    c) N-to-1 funneling is interesting but more complex and may be too large for a first demonstration.\n  Step 3: Choose (a) heralded \u221aSWAP between polarization and THz qubit.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no previous Pytheus example implements the partial\u2010swap gate (\u221aSWAP) between two abstract qubits, especially mixing two different DOFs (polarization \u2194 frequency bins). \u221aSWAP is the quintessential \u201chalf\u2010period\u201d of an exchange (Jaynes\u2013Cummings) coupling, so this directly mimics a strong light\u2013matter interaction in a purely linear-optics network.\n  Step 5: This is feasible in Pytheus because:\n    \u2022 We only need two logical qubits (abstract modes: one 2D polarization, one 2D frequency-bin).\n    \u2022 Target is a well\u2010defined unitary on four basis states\u2014Pytheus can optimize beam\u2010splitter networks + ancillas to realize it heraldedly.\n    \u2022 No cavities or dynamic feedback are required\u2014just probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, detectors.\n    \u2022 It generalizes immediately: higher-dimensional \u221aSWAP, cascaded \u221aSWAP chains, hybrid\u2010DOF quantum routers.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:  \n  Heralded partial\u2010SWAP (\u221aSWAP) gate between a polarization qubit and a THz-frequency-bin qubit, simulating half a Jaynes\u2013Cummings exchange in a pure linear-optics network.\n\nExplanation:  \n  We label four photons/modes as follows:  \n    \u2022 Mode 0 carries a polarization qubit |\u03c8\u27e9_pol to be transformed.  \n    \u2022 Mode 1 carries a frequency-bin qubit in two THz-spaced bins {\u03c9\u2080,\u03c9\u2081}.  \n    \u2022 Modes 2\u20135 are ancillary photons used to herald the gate.  \n\n  Protocol:  \n    1) Prepare two photon\u2010pair sources (S\u2081, S\u2082) that each emit one polarization\u2013polarization Bell pair:  \n       S\u2081\u2192(0,2_pol): |00>+|11>,  S\u2082\u2192(1,3_freq): |\u03c9\u2080\u03c9\u2080>+|\u03c9\u2081\u03c9\u2081>.  \n    2) Introduce four additional ancillary photons (modes 4\u20137) from two more pair sources.  \n    3) Feed modes 0&1 and ancillas 4\u20137 into a 6\u00d76 linear-optics network optimized to implement the 4\u00d74 sub\u2010unitary corresponding to \u221aSWAP in the computational basis {00,01,10,11}:  \n         U_{\u221aSWAP} = diag(1,(1+i)/2,(1+i)/2,1) plus appropriate off-diagonals for the swap half-period.  \n    4) Condition on a specific four-click pattern at detectors on ancilla modes 4\u20137. Upon that herald, the remaining photons exit on modes 2&3 having undergone \u221aSWAP:  \n         |i\u27e9\u2080|j\u27e9\u2081 \u2192 U_{\u221aSWAP}|i\u27e9\u2082|j\u27e9\u2083.  \n\nConfig Sketch (to feed into Pytheus):  \n{  \n  'description': 'Heralded \u221aSWAP gate between polarization qubit and THz frequency-bin qubit.',  \n  'foldername': 'heralded_sqrt_swap_pol2thz',  \n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,  \n  'edges_tried': 30,  \n  'ftol': 1e-06,  \n  'loss_func': 'cr',  \n  'num_pre': 4,          # list of 4 output 2-photon bitstrings with \u221aSWAP amplitudes  \n    '00 00 1.0+0.0j',  \n    '01 10 0.5+0.5j',  \n    '10 01 0.5+0.5j',  \n    '11 11 1.0+0.0j'  \n  ],  \n  'in_nodes': [0,1],     # This builds directly on entanglement swapping/teleportation but adds a control qubit in a different DOF (THz bins), producing a genuine new network transformation not in Pytheus\u2019s existing library.\n  Step 2: This is novel because no prior Pytheus design implements a controlled teleportation or \u201cquantum switch\u201d between arbitrary nodes, especially where the control is encoded in a THz-frequency qubit and the signal is polarization. \n  Step 3: It is feasible in Pytheus because it only uses four probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, joint measurements, and heralding detectors\u2014no cavities or feedback\u2014exactly Pytheus\u2019s supported primitives. I propose implementing a three\u2010way indefinite\u2010order entanglement\u2010swap (\u201ctriple\u2010SWITCH\u201d) controlled by a THz\u2010frequency qutrit. The control photon, encoded in three THz\u2010spaced frequency bins, coherently superposes three different orders in which three entanglement\u2010swap stations act on three adjacent Bell pairs. The output is an entangled state of the control and two distant polarization photons, signaling genuine indefinite causal order in a multi\u2010hop network.  \n\nThis is novel because no prior Pytheus target fuses multi\u2010swap causal superposition with a high\u2010dimensional control, and it directly probes foundational questions about causality in quantum networks. It\u2019s feasible in the Pytheus framework\u2014requiring only four probabilistic pair\u2010sources, a 6\u00d76 linear\u2010optics block plus two heralding detectors\u2014and it generalizes to longer swap chains or higher\u2010D controls.   \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  Three-way indefinite\u2010order entanglement swapping, controlled by a THz-frequency qutrit. A single control photon in one of three frequency bins {\u03c9\u2080,\u03c9\u2081,\u03c9\u2082} (\u0394\u03c9\u2248THz) coherently selects the order in which three swap stations perform Bell-measurements on three polarization-Bell pairs spanning nodes A\u2192C\u2192D\u2192E\u2192B. The result is a 3-party entangled state between the control and the end nodes A and B, certifying indefinite causal order in a repeater chain.\n\nExplanation:\n  Resources (four probabilistic pair sources):\n    S\u2081 \u2192 modes (1_pol,2_pol): Bell pair A\u2013C  \n    S\u2082 \u2192 modes (3_pol,4_pol): Bell pair C\u2013D  \n    S\u2083 \u2192 modes (5_pol,6_pol): Bell pair D\u2013E  \n    S\u2084 \u2192 modes (0_freq,7_freq): control qutrit in frequency bins\n\n  Ancillas: two photons from S\u2085 (modes 8,9) for heralding.\n\n  Modes at the central station (Charlie\u2019s lab): 0_freq, 2_pol, 4_pol, 6_pol, plus ancillas 8,9. Upon herald, the surviving photons on modes 1 (A_out) and 6 (B_out), together with mode 0 (control), emerge in the entangled superposition\n\n    |\u03a8_final\u27e9 = ( |\u03c9\u2080\u27e9\u2080 \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{1,6} \n                + |\u03c9\u2081\u27e9\u2080 \u2297 |\u03a8\u207a\u27e9_{1,6} \n                + |\u03c9\u2082\u27e9\u2080 \u2297 |\u03a6\u207b\u27e9_{1,6} ) /\u221a3\n\n  where |\u03a6\u00b1\u27e9 and |\u03a8\u207a\u27e9 are the three distinct two-qubit Bell states, each arising from a different swap order.\n\nPytheus Config Sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Three-way indefinite\u2010order entanglement swap controlled by THz frequency qutrit.',\n  'foldername': 'thz_indefinite_swap3',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 50,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_pre': 5,                  # S1\u2013S4 for the three Bell pairs + control; S5 for ancillas\n  'num_anc': 2,                  # two heralding photons (modes 8,9)\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 30,\n  'target_quantum': [\n    # Format: 'in_bits out_bits amplitude'\n    # in_bits index modes [0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7], out_bits index [0,1,6]\n    # Here we list the three nonzero terms:\n    '0 00000000 0 00 0  1.0',    # \u03c9\u2080 \u00d7 \u03a6\u207a on modes 1&6\n    '1 00000000 1 01 1  1.0',    # \u03c9\u2081 \u00d7 \u03a8\u207a on modes 1&6\n    '2 00000000 2 10 0  1.0'     # \u03c9\u2082 \u00d7 \u03a6\u207b on modes 1&6\n  ],\n  'in_nodes':    [0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  'out_nodes':   [0,1,6],\n  'anc_detectors':[8,9],\n  'single_emitters':[],\n  'removed_connections': []\n}\n\nVisual Layout:\n  S\u2084 \u2192 (0_freq,7_freq)  control\n  S\u2081 \u2192 (1_pol,2_pol)    A\u2013C\n  S\u2082 \u2192 (3_pol,4_pol)    C\u2013D\n  S\u2083 \u2192 (5_pol,6_pol)    D\u2013E\n  S\u2085 \u2192 (8,9)            ancillas\n              \u2502\n              \u2514\u2500\u25b6 [6\u00d76 linear-optics network at Charlie mixing modes 0,2,4,6,8,9]\n                      \u2514\u2500\u25b6 detectors on 8,9 (herald)\n                             \u2502\n                          Outputs: 0(control), 1(A_out), 6(B_out)\n\nGeneralizations:\n  \u2022 Extend to N swap stations with an N-dimensional THz control, superposing N! causal orders.  \n  \u2022 Investigate violations of causal inequalities in quantum\u2010network distribution.  \n  \u2022 Build higher-order supermaps of teleporters or distillation modules under quantum control.\n\nThis experiment directly probes indefinite causal order in multi-node quantum repeaters, combining THz\u2010domain DOFs with foundational quantum\u2010network operations, and Pytheus can optimize the required beam-splitter network and heralding scheme.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates the known three-order entanglement-swap SWITCH. To be novel, you must propose a genuinely new higher-order process or measurement primitive beyond this existing indefinite-order swap supermap.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Thought:\n  I will propose a truly new network primitive: a heralded, THz\u2010frequency\u2010qubit\u2013controlled two\u2010photon conditional\u2010phase gate (C_\u03c6) on two polarization qubits.  Here a single photon in two THz\u2010separated frequency bins {|\u03c9\u2080\u27e9,|\u03c9\u2081\u27e9} \u201cprograms\u201d whether the polarization qubits pick up a phase \u03c6 on their |VV\u27e9 (|11\u27e9) component\u2014i.e. \u03c6=0 for \u03c9\u2080 (do nothing) and \u03c6=\u03c0 for \u03c9\u2081 (apply CZ). This simulates a tunable, resonant strong light\u2013matter interaction at THz spacing. It is a bona\u2010fide quantum\u2010network transformation (no raw state generation), uses only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, joint measurements and heralding detectors, and can be generalized to arbitrary \u03c6 or higher\u2010D frequency controls.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  Heralded THz\u2010frequency\u2010qubit\u2013controlled polarization on modes 1&3 (|H\u27e9\u22610,|V\u27e9\u22611).  \n  When c=\u03c9\u2080 apply C_0\u2261I; when c=\u03c9\u2081 apply C_\u03c0\u2261CZ on t\u2081&t\u2082.\n\nResources:\n  \u2022 S\u2081\u2192(0_freq, 4_freq): control Bell pair |\u03c9\u2080\u03c9\u2080\u27e9+|\u03c9\u2081\u03c9\u2081\u27e9  \n  \u2022 S\u2082\u2192(1_pol, 5_pol): data\u2010qubit 1 + ancilla for herald  \n  \u2022 S\u2083\u2192(3_pol, 6_pol): data\u2010qubit 2 + ancilla for herald  \n  \u2022 S\u2084\u2192(7,8): two ancilla photons for success heralding  \n\nProtocol:\n  1) Inject modes {0,1,3,4,5,6,7,8} into an 8\u00d78 linear\u2010optics network.  \n  2) Post\u2010select on a specific four\u2010click pattern on ancilla detectors {5,6,7,8}.  \n  3) Upon herald, remaining photons on modes 4 (control out), 1 & 3 (data out) realize:\n     |c,t\u2081,t\u2082\u27e9 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2009\u2297\u2009C_{\u03c6(c)}\u2009|t\u2081,t\u2082\u27e9  \n     with \u03c6(\u03c9\u2080)=0,     "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Catalytic Entanglement Amplification of Bell Pairs via a Squeezed-Reservoir Ancilla in Pure LOQC\n\nAbstract: We present a static LOQC circuit that catalytically amplifies the entanglement of two weak Bell pairs in modes (A,B) and (C,D) using a non-maximally entangled squeezed-reservoir ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082). By mixing modes {B,R\u2081} and {C,R\u2082} on two beam splitters and post-selecting on a fixed two-click photon-number pattern at detectors on B and C, the protocol realizes the target transformation in which modes A and D emerge in a stronger Bell-like state |00\u27e9+K(\u03b1,r)|11\u27e9 while the squeezed ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082) is returned unchanged.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a single-shot four-body stabilizer readout for the smallest toric-code plaquette by Bell-entangling each of four data photons with an ancilla photon and sending all ancilla modes through a 4\u00d74 passive interferometer equipped with number-resolving detectors. Heralded two-photon click patterns in even or odd detector pairs directly project the data qubits onto the \u00b11 eigenstates of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084, realizing a direct stabilizer measurement without any feed-forward or dynamic control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photon-Blockade-Assisted Entanglement Purification of Noisy Bell Pairs\n\nAbstract: We introduce a static linear-optical protocol that combines two probabilistic noisy Bell-pair sources with single-emitter photon-blockade nodes to suppress double-pair emissions and distill the target high-fidelity Bell state |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9=(|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9)/\u221a2. By performing a parity check on one photon from each pair via a 50:50 beam splitter and enforcing \u22641-photon inputs through photon-blockade ancillae, specific heralding detection patterns project the remaining photons onto the purified Bell state within the PyTheus framework.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Telecom-Band Frequency-Bin Teleportation MUX for Qubit\u2192Ququart Isometry\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a fully passive, measurement-assisted linear-optical circuit that fuses two qubits, each encoded in a Kerr microcomb\u2019s telecom-band frequency bins, into a single ququart channel via teleportation.  Using two probabilistic Bell-pair photon sources, ancilla modes, a static interferometer and photon-number-resolving detectors, the heralded Choistate  \n\u2211_{i,j\u2208{0,1}} |i,j\u27e9_in |2i+j\u27e9_out  \nrealizes the isometry mapping |00\u27e9\u2192|0\u27e9, |01\u27e9\u2192|1\u27e9, |10\u27e9\u2192|2\u27e9 and |11\u27e9\u2192|3\u27e9 without dynamic feed-forward or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Ancilla-Controlled Programmable Coherent Bell Analyzer\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and simulate a fully coherent measurement supermap\u2014targeting programmable photonic quantum processors\u2014that employs a single Purcell-enhanced on-demand emitter as ancilla (mode 2) to coherently choose between Z- and X-basis Bell measurements on two SPDC-generated photons (modes 0 & 1) within a static linear-optical network. By entangling the control qubit (mode 3) with the Bell-outcome recorded on four ancilla detectors (modes 4\u20137), this design realizes the first programmable photonic Bell analyzer in PyTheus, obviating active switching or teleportation for coherent basis selection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Photonic Witness for Direct Three-Tangle Estimation\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a hybrid quantum-classical photonic device that learns a tunable linear-optical circuit and classical weightings to directly estimate the three-tangle of an unknown three-photon state. By employing ancilla Bell-pair sources, number-resolving detectors, and a classical optimizer to adjust beam-splitter reflectivities and post-processing coefficients, our variational algorithm approximates the genuine tripartite entanglement measure purely from click statistics.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \n2\u00d72 Entanglement Percolation Network for Semi-Quantum Key Distribution  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe target the implementation of a 2\u00d72 quantum percolation network for semi-quantum key distribution (SQKD) in a purely linear-optical, P\u2006ytheus-compatible setup. Four probabilistic photon-pair sources sit on the grid\u2019s edges and feed two static Bell analyzers at the diagonal midpoints whose heralded outcomes percolate entanglement across opposite corner nodes; the classical corners then perform only reflection or Z-basis measurement to extract correlated raw key bits.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Topologically Protected On-Demand Entanglement Switch in an SSH-Star Nanofiber Network\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a star-shaped quantum switch composed of N identical optical nanofiber SSH chains that meet at a single topological defect, whose zero-energy hub modes are mixed in a programmable multiport beam-splitter to route entanglement. By injecting probabilistic Bell-pair photons at each branch tip, engineering alternating strong/weak static beam-splitter couplings, and performing a heralded Bell measurement on any two chosen hub modes, the device projects the corresponding edge photons into the target two-qubit Bell state on-demand, all realized within PythEus\u2019s linear-optics optimization framework.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a heralded linear-optical protocol that entangles two remote static phase shifts \u03c6_A and \u03c6_B via an ancilla-assisted CPHASE gate, imprinting the nonlinear product cos\u2009\u03c6_A\u00b7cos\u2009\u03c6_B into the conditioned joint click probability. By calibrating and subtracting the individual cos\u2009\u03c6_A and cos\u2009\u03c6_B fringes, the scheme isolates the target phase product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B and attains near-Heisenberg scaling in Fisher information with full loss tolerance.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Teleportation-Based Nonlocal Controlled-Phase Gate (CPhase\u2083) for Two Qutrits\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present a PytHeus-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a controlled\u2010phase gate CPhase\u2083 across two remote qutrits A and B by using two entangled Bell-like qutrit photon pairs, four ancillary photons, and Charlie\u2019s joint ancilla measurement to herald successful post-selected gate application. The resulting single\u2010click detector events yield a fully quantized classifier response targeting photonic qudit state discrimination as a new quantum\u2010metric machine\u2010learning primitive.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). The successful eight-fold coincidence projects detectors 0\u20133 and 12\u201315 onto the unnormalized target quantum state  \n[\"00000000\", \"00001111\", \"11110000\", \"11111111\", \"00110011\", \"00111100\", \"11000011\", \"11001100\"],  \nheralding a fault-tolerant logical Bell pair between A and D without any feed-forward correction.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Indefinite-Order Photonic Superchannel Switch\n\nAbstract: We target the design of an integrated-photonic \u201csuperchannel switch\u201d that coherently superposes two distinct quantum network primitives\u2014entanglement swapping (ES) and quantum teleportation (QT)\u2014in indefinite causal order. The scheme realizes the Ising-anyon associator F as a 2\u00d72 unitary mapping the ((Q\u2081Q\u2082)(Q\u2083Q\u2084)) fusion basis to (Q\u2081(Q\u2082Q\u2083)Q\u2084), thereby demonstrating a fundamental non-Abelian operation with only beam splitters, phase shifters, photon-pair sources, number-resolving detectors, and post-selection.Title: Measurement-Induced Topological Percolation for High-Fidelity Qubit Teleportation on a Bell-Pair Toroidal Lattice  \n\nAbstract: We propose a passive linear-optical experiment in which an L\u00d7L toroidal array of probabilistic Bell-pair photon sources and static Bell-state measurement modules undergoes postselected entanglement swapping to drive a topological percolation transition. By restricting all Bell-pair sources, beam splitters, and photon-number-resolving detectors to allowed edge bonds, the scheme exploits the nontrivial Chern band topology to maintain robustness against static bulk defects and connectivity disorder.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Anti-PT Topological Bell-State Analyzer for Deterministic Four-State Discrimination\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a linear-optics network incorporating an anti-PT\u2013symmetric SSH loop of beam splitters driven by two ancillary photon-pair sources to realize a complete four-outcome Bell measurement. This measurement swaps entanglement onto photons 2 (freq) and 0\u20131 pair, effectively imprinting |\u03c8> onto the frequency\u2010bin DOF of photon 2.\n    \u2013 Photon 2 is then already the teleported state in frequency bins; to complete, one can swap frequency\u2010bin labels via a swap test into photon 3.\n  Abstract Target Quantum (over four modes 0\u20133):\n    List amplitudes for the four\u2010mode basis that encode this teleportation (cf. standard qubit teleportation but replacing the teleported output mode with frequency\u2010bin labels).\n  Config Sketch:\n    \u2022 num_pre: 1 (one prepare stage with two probabilistic pair sources)\n    \u2022 num_anc: 0 (no extra ancillas; supermap: if control=\u03c9_k, perform the k-th swap chain out of D options\u2014for example:  \n       k=0: no swap (identity on A\u2013B),  \n       k=1: swap S\u2081\u2192S\u2083 (two-stage chain     "output": "Thought: While encoding the control qubit in THz\u2010frequency bins to drive a CZ on polarization qubits is neat, it doesn\u2019t introduce a genuinely new network primitive beyond existing spectral\u2010controlled, measurement\u2010induced gates (e.g. the spectral\u2010controlled SWAP router and ancilla\u2010programmed Bell analyzers in the ensemble). Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. On one side, encode a polarization qubit; on the other, encode a qubit into two specific THz\u2010separated frequency modes. Perform a Bell\u2010state measurement that \u201cswaps\u201d the polarization qubit into the frequency\u2010bin DOF, effectively simulating a strong light\u2013matter coupling (polariton) interface between polarization and frequency. Then teleport that qubit onward.\n    b) Hybrid Node Network Emulating THz Strong Coupling via Ancillary High\u2010Dimensional Mode:\n       \u2013 Build a three\u2010node network A\u2013C\u2013B. A\u2013C share a 2D Bell pair, C\u2013B share a D\u2010dimensional Bell pair (D\u226b2), where the extra dimensions emulate matter excitations at THz energy splittings. At C, perform a joint measurement across the 2D and D\u2010dimensional systems (a \u201chybrid\u201d Bell measurement) that enacts an entanglement swap and simulates the strong coupling between light (2D) and matter (D\u2010dimensional THz manifold). This teleports A\u2019s qubit into B\u2019s high\u2010D mode.\n    c) Teleportation of a Qubit through Simulated Polaritonic Modes Using Ancillary THz\u2010Bin Photons:\n       \u2013 Prepare two three\u2010party entangled GHZ\u2010like links: one in polarization and one in THz\u2010frequency bins. Obstacle: Pytheus requires abstract bins; however frequency bins are just abstract high\u2010dimensional modes, so feasible.\n    b) Novel\u2014hybrid Bell measurement between different dimensions; no direct analog in list. Obstacle: specifying a joint measurement across different subsystems is expressible as target amplitudes.\n    c) More complex\u2014GHZ in two DOFs and GHZ\u2010swap; likely too intricate and may strain Pytheus\u2019s loss\u2010function calibration.\n  Step 3: Pick (a) Frequency\u2010Bin Teleportation;\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it explicitly combines a two\u2010dimensional polarization qubit with a THz\u2010spaced high\u2010dimensional frequency\u2010bin entangled channel in an entanglement\u2010swapping/teleportation protocol. No previous Pytheus target mixes low\u2010D and high\u2010D modes in this manner or references THz spacing.\n  Step 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because:\n    \u2022 It defines an abstract two\u2010mode (polarization) system and an abstract N\u2010mode (frequency bins) system\u2014both allowed.\n    \u2022 The target is an entanglement swapping/teleportation of an abstract qubit, without focusing on physical state generation.\n    \u2022 No feedback control or cavities are needed\u2014only linear optics, probabilistic pair sources, and joint measurements.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription: Teleportation of a polarization qubit into a THz\u2010spaced frequency\u2010bin qudit via entanglement swapping, simulating a strong light\u2013matter coupling interface.\nExplanation:\n  We consider two distinct DOFs:\n    \u2013 Qubit (polarization) at node A.\n    \u2013 Qubit encoded into two THz\u2010separated frequency bins at node B.\n  We start with:\n    1) A polarization Bell pair between A (photon 0) and C (photon 1): |00>_pol + |11>_pol.\n    2) A 2\u2010bin frequency\u2010bin Bell pair between C (photon 2) and B (photon 3): |\u03c91,\u03c91> + |\u03c92,\u03c92>, where \u0394\u03c9 \u2248 THz.\n  Goal: teleport an arbitrary polarization state |\u03c8> on photon 0 to the two\u2010bin frequency qubit on detector 3.\n  Protocol:\n    \u2013 Alice (node A) holds photon 0 in unknown polarization |\u03c8>.\n    \u2013 Charlie at node C holds photons 1 and 2 (one in polarization, one in frequency bins).\n    \u2013 Charlie performs a joint Bell\u2010state measurement between photons 0 and 1 across polarization modes. These come from two independent Bell\u2010pair sources S1 (modes 0&2) and S2 (modes 1&3).\n  \u2013 Node D will output a single photon 4 encoded into four abstract frequency bins {\u03c90,\u03c91,\u03c92,\u03c93} with bin spacing \u0394\u03c9 \u2248 THz, i.e. a ququart.\n\nGoal: implement the isometry\n  |i\u27e9\u2080|j\u27e9\u2081 \u2192 |\u03c9_{2i + j}\u27e9\u2084   for i,j \u2208 {0,1},\nso that the joint polarization state of A&B is coherently \u201cfunnelled\u201d into one higher\u2010dimensional THz mode at D.\n\nProtocol (entanglement\u2010swap style):\n  1) Prepare S1: a polarization Bell pair on modes 0 & 2: |00>+|11>.\n  2) Prepare S2: a polarization Bell pair on modes 1 & 3: |00>+|11>.\n  3) At node C, interfere photons 2&3 in a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics network engineered to implement a joint measurement whose successful heralding projects those two photons onto one of four predefined two\u2010qubit Bell\u2010like basis states. The outcome determines which of the four frequency bins \u03c9_k at mode 4 carries the combined label (2i+j).\n  4) Conditioned on the heralded detection at C, photon 4 emerges in the target ququart state |\u03c9_{2i + j}\u27e9\u2084, faithfully representing the original two\u2010qubit state.\n\nAbstract Target Quantum:\n We define a four\u2010mode computational basis for modes 0,1,4:\n   { |0\u20800\u2081\u03c9\u2080\u2084>, |0\u20801\u2081\u03c9\u2081\u2084>, |1\u20800\u2081\u03c9\u2082\u2084>, |1\u20801\u2081\u03c9\u2083\u2084> } \n(with appropriate complex phases set by the joint measurement outcomes).\n The target amplitude list is then the identity map on that basis.\n\nConfig Sketch:\n  num_pre: 2                      # two pair sources\n  num_anc: 0                      # no extra ancillas beyond 4 photons\n  single_emitters: []\n  removed_connections: []         # sources only to their designated pairs\n  loss_func: 'cr'\n  samples: 10\n  target_quantum: [\n    '000\u03c90',  # basis mapping, indices are abstract labels\n    '011\u03c91',\n    '100\u03c92',\n    '111\u03c93'\n  ]\n  in_nodes: [0,1]\n  out_nodes: [4]\n  anc_detectors: [2,3]\n  # Any required \u201clookup table\u201d for detector patterns \u2192 bin index is part of the post\u2010processing.\n\nVisual Layout:\n  S1 \u2192 (0,2_pol)  \n               \u2198 \n                 \u25b6\u2500[4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics joint\u2010measurement block at C]\u2500\u2197\u2500 heralded detectors (2,3)\n               \u2197  \n  S2 \u2192 (1,3_pol)  \n\n  Post-selected on one of 4 click-patterns at detectors 2&3, output mode 4 emerges in one of the four frequency bins \u03c9\u2080\u2026\u03c9\u2083.\n\nThis network realizes a nontrivial conversion: it \u201cstrongly couples\u201d two polarization qubits (matter\u2010like excitations) into one THz\u2010spaced frequency\u2010bin photon (light\u2010like output). This gate directly simulates a conditional polaritonic coupling (only when the THz exciton qubit is \u201c1\u201d do the two polarization excitations swap).\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n    \u2022 Target is a well\u2010defined 8\u00d78 unitary (the Fredkin truth table) on three abstract qubits\u2014Pytheus can optimize photonic circuits + ancillas to implement any heralded unitary.\n    \u2022 Uses only pair sources, linear optics, and photon\u2010counting detectors (no cavities or feedback).\n    \u2022 Fully generalizes: change the control to an N\u2010bin frequency qudit for higher\u2010order conditional gates; cascade Fredkins for multi\u2010mode polaritonic networks.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  Implement a heralded Fredkin (controlled\u2010SWAP) gate in linear optics where:\n   \u2022 The control qubit is encoded in two THz\u2010spaced frequency bins (modes 0 & 1).\n   \u2022 The two target qubits are polarization\u2010encoded photons (modes 2 & 3).\n  When the frequency\u2010bin qubit is |1\u27e9, the two polarization qubits swap; when it is |0\u27e9, they remain unchanged. This mimics a THz\u2010resonant conditional exchange (strong light\u2013matter coupling) between two polarization excitations.\n\nProtocol Outline:\n  1) Prepare four probabilistic pair sources:\n     S\u2081 \u2192 (0,4): frequency\u2010bin Bell pair |\u03c9\u2080\u03c9\u2080>+|\u03c9\u2081\u03c9\u2081>  \n     S\u2082 \u2192 (1,5): polarization Bell pair |HH>+|VV>  \n     S\u2083,S\u2084 \u2192 (6\u20139): two additional Bell pairs as ancillas  \n  2) Inject modes 0\u20133 (the logical control & targets) and ancillas 6\u20139 into a 7\u00d77 linear\u2010optics circuit optimized by Pytheus to implement the 8\u00d78 Fredkin unitary U_F.  \n  3) Condition on a specific four\u2010click pattern at detectors on ancilla modes 6\u20139. Upon herald, the remaining photons exit on modes 4\u20135 (control) and 2\u20133 (targets), having undergone:\n      U_F\u2009|c,t\u2081,t\u2082\u27e9 = |c\u27e9\u2009\u2297\u2009{ if c=1 then |t\u2082,t\u2081\u27e9 else |t\u2081,t\u2082\u27e9 }.  \n\nAbstract Target Quantum (eight 6\u2010bit strings \u201cin\u2192out\u201d):\n  '000000'  \n  '001001'  \n  '010010'  \n  '011011'  \n  '100011'  \n  '101100'  \n  '110101'  \n  '111110'  \n\nPytheus Config Sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Heralded Fredkin gate: control in THz frequency bins, targets in polarization modes.',\n  'foldername': 'fredkin_pol_freq',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_pre': 4,            # This builds directly on entanglement swapping/teleportation but adds a control qubit in a different DOF (THz bins), producing a genuine new network transformation not in Pytheus\u2019s existing library.\n  Step 2: This is novel because no prior Pytheus design implements a controlled teleportation or \u201cquantum switch\u201d between arbitrary nodes, especially where the control is encoded in a THz-frequency qubit and the signal is polarization. \n  Step 3: It is feasible in Pytheus because it only uses four probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, joint measurements, and heralding detectors\u2014no cavities or feedback\u2014exactly Pytheus\u2019s supported primitives. We define an 8\u00d78 target unitary mapping for the three logical qubits (control + signal + two \u201cblank\u201d Bell outputs) and four ancillas.\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  Heralded Quantum Router via THz-Controlled Entanglement Swapping.\n  We have three logical qubits:\n    \u2022 Control qubit c encoded in two THz-separated frequency bins on mode 0.\n    \u2022 Signal qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 encoded in polarization on mode 1.\n    \u2022 Two \u201cdestination\u201d qubits B and D initially in blank states (each half of a Bell resource).\n  Resources (four probabilistic pair sources):\n    S\u2081 \u2192 (mode 1,2) creates the signal\u2013bus Bell pair in polarization: |HH>+|VV>.\n    S\u2082 \u2192 (mode 3,4) creates a Bell pair destined for node B in polarization.\n    S\u2083 \u2192 (mode 5,6) creates a Bell pair destined for node D in polarization.\n    S\u2084 \u2192 (mode 0,7) creates the control\u2013ancilla Bell pair in frequency bins: |\u03c9\u2080\u03c9\u2080>+|\u03c9\u2081\u03c9\u2081>, \u0394\u03c9\u2248THz.\n  Ancilla photons on modes 2,4,6,7 are measured by a central router (Charlie) in one joint multi-photon projection.\n  Protocol:\n    \u2022 Charlie mixes modes {0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7} in a tailored 8\u00d78 linear-optics network and conditions on a specific four-click heralding pattern on ancilla detectors at modes {2,4,6,7}.\n    \u2022 Upon that herald, the control qubit exits on mode 0\u2032 (unchanged), and the signal qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 is teleported to either node B (mode 3\u2032) if c=\u03c9\u2080 or to node D (mode 5\u2032) if c=\u03c9\u2081.\n    \u2022 If c=\u03c9\u2080, the Bell pair S\u2082 is consumed and B receives |\u03c8\u27e9; if c=\u03c9\u2081, B receives the blank partner of S\u2082 (|0\u27e9) and D receives |\u03c8\u27e9.\n  Abstract Target Quantum (input\u2192output labels; 3 logical qubits c,s,t plus 4 ancillas a):\n    We label basis states as |c s b d ;\u2009a2 a4 a6 a7\u27e9\u208din\u208e \u2192 |c ;\u2009b\u2032 d\u2032\u27e9\u208dout\u208e \u2297 |herald\u27e9,\n    with the mapping:\n      for c=0 (\u03c9\u2080): |0,s,0,0;0000\u27e9\u2192|0;b=s,d=0\u27e9  \n      for c=1 (\u03c9\u2081): |1,s,0,0;0000\u27e9\u2192|1;b=0,d=s\u27e9  \n    (All off-diagonal amplitudes zero, phases chosen real.)\nPytheus Config Sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Heralded quantum router: control in THz bins, signal in polarization, routes to B or D.',\n  'foldername': 'thz_controlled_router',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 50,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_pre': 4,                 # four Bell-pair sources\n  'num_anc': 4,                 # four ancilla photons (modes 2,4,6,7)\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 20,\n  'target_quantum': [\n    '00000000 0  s 0 0',  # c=0,s, b\u2032=s,d\u2032=0\n    '10000000 1 0 0 s'    # c=1,s, b\u2032=0,d\u2032=s\n  ],\n  'in_nodes': [0,1,3,5],        # control(0), signal(1), B-input(3), D-input(5)\n  'out_nodes': [0,3,5],         # control(0), B-out(3), D-out(5)\n  'anc_detectors': [2,4,6,7],   # modes to herald\n  'single_emitters': [],\n  'removed_connections': []\n}\nVisual Layout:\n  S\u2081 \u2192 modes 1&2 (pol)\n  S\u2082 \u2192 modes 3&4 (pol)\n  S\u2083 \u2192 modes 5&6 (pol)\n  S\u2084 \u2192 modes 0&7 (freq)\n           \u2502\n           \u2514\u2500\u25b6 [8\u00d78 linear-optics router network at Charlie] \u2500\u25b6 Detectors on {2,4,6,7}\n                       \u2502\n                  Outputs: control\u2192mode0; No existing Pytheus experiment features a quantum\u2010controlled Bell\u2010measurement basis.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus:\n    \u2022 Defines two polarization\u2010encoded Bell pairs (A\u2013C, C\u2013B) plus one D\u2010dimensional THz control qudit at C\u2014all abstract modes.\n    \u2022 The target is a measurement\u2010induced network: the joint unitary+projection that maps input modes (two pol. qubits + one freq qudit) to one of D entangled outputs between A and B, correlated with control. He performs a single joint measurement which, controlled by the state |k\u27e9_\u03c9 on mode 4_freq, projects modes (1,2) onto the k-th generalised Bell basis. Upon heralding that measurement, modes 0_pol (Alice) and 3_pol (Bob) become entangled in the corresponding k-th Bell\u2010like state.\n   \u2022 This realizes a quantum\u2010controlled entanglement\u2010swap: the THz qudit programs which entangled state A\u2013B emerge in, all in one measurement step.\n\nAbstract Target Mapping:\n  Input basis: |b\u2080,b\u2081; b\u2082,b\u2083; k\u27e9  where b\u1d62\u2208{0,1} are polarizations on modes 0\u20133, k\u2208{0\u2026D\u22121} is THz bin on mode 4.\n  Output (post\u2010selected) on modes 0&3:\n    |b\u2080,b\u2083\u27e9 \u2192 the k-th Bell basis vector  \n  Control qudit is consumed in the measurement; herald detectors read out k.\n  In amplitude form, for each k we have\n    \u2211_{x,y=0,1}  (\u22121)^{f_k(x,y)} |x\u2080,y\u2083\u27e9\u27e8x\u2081,y\u2082;k\u2084|  \n  where f_k(x,y) encodes the phase pattern of the k-th generalised Bell basis.\n\nPytheus Config Sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Programmable entanglement swapping: THz\u2010freq control qudit selects Bell basis',\n  'foldername': 'thz_controlled_swap',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 50,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_pre': 3,                # Pytheus can optimize any heralded, linear\u2010optics network for a specified unitary or measurement\u2010induced map.\n  Step 3: Select (3).\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it goes beyond static gate primitives\u2014it implements a true \u201cquantum SWITCH\u201d of two entanglement\u2010swap operations, putting the causal order in superposition. No existing Pytheus experiment explores indefinite causal order in entanglement distribution.\n  Step 5: This is feasible in Pytheus because:\n    \u2022 We only need abstract polarization qubits and a 2\u2010bin frequency control qubit\u2014exactly what Pytheus can handle.\n    \u2022 The target is a heralded transformation from three Bell\u2010pair inputs + control qubit \u2192 entangled A\u2013B output + preserved control coherence, expressed as a list of input\u2192output amplitudes.\n    \u2022 It uses only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, joint\u2010measurement blocks, and photon\u2010counting heralds\u2014no cavities or feedback.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  Implement a heralded quantum SWITCH of two entanglement\u2010swap operations, controlled by a THz\u2010frequency\u2010bin qubit.  The control qubit |c\u27e9_freq \u2208{|\u03c9\u2080>,|\u03c9\u2081>} (\u0394\u03c9\u2248THz) coherently routes the order in which Charlie performs two Bell\u2010measurements\n    \u2022 Swap\u20101 at node C on modes (A\u2013C, C\u2013D)\n    \u2022 Swap\u20102 at node D on modes (C\u2013D, D\u2013B)\n  When c=\u03c9\u2080 the network does Swap\u20101\u2192Swap\u20102; when c=\u03c9\u2081 it does Swap\u20102\u2192Swap\u20101.  In superposition, both orders occur, entangling A and B while preserving the control coherence.\n\nResources & Modes:\n  \u2013 S\u2081: Bell pair on A\u2013C in polarization (modes 1&2): |HH>+|VV>  \n  \u2013 S\u2082: Bell pair on C\u2013D in polarization (modes 3&4): |HH>+|VV>  \n  \u2013 S\u2083: Bell pair on D\u2013B in polarization (modes 5&6): |HH>+|VV>  \n  \u2013 S\u2084: Bell pair for control on mode 0_freq & ancilla 7_freq: |\u03c9\u2080\u03c9\u2080>+|\u03c9\u2081\u03c9\u2081>  \n\nCharlie\u2019s station mixes modes {0,2,3,4,5,7} plus two additional ancilla modes (8,9) in a linear\u2010optics network that implements the controlled superposition of performing the two Bell measurements in the two orders. He heralds on specific four\u2010click patterns at detectors on modes {8,9,4,5}.  \n\nProtocol & Target Mapping:\n  Input basis labelled |c;h\u2081,h\u2082;h\u2083,h\u2084;h\u2085,h\u2086\u27e9  for control c\u2208{0,1} (\u03c9\u2080\u21920, \u03c9\u2081\u21921) and Bell\u2010pair bits h\u1d62\u2208{0,1}.  \n  After the SWITCH\u2010network + herald, the output on modes 1 (A) & 6 (B) is always the same Bell state |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9, but the joint control\u2010swap history remains coherent.  Concretely:\n    |c\u27e9\u2080 \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{12} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{34} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{56}\n      \u2192 (1/\u221a2)[|0\u27e9|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{A,B}\u23aeorder=C\u2192D\u27e9 + |1\u27e9|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{A,B}\u23aeorder=D\u2192C\u27e9].\n\nPytheus Config Sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Quantum SWITCH of two entanglement\u2010swap operations, controlled by a THz\u2010frequency\u2010bin qubit.',\n  'foldername': 'thz_controlled_swap_switch',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 60,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_pre': 4,                # S1,S2,S3 for swaps + S4 for control\n  'num_anc': 4,                # ancilla photons for heralding\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 30,\n  'target_quantum': [\n    # Pairs of input\u2192output 8\u2010photon bitstrings with c\u2010conditional SWAP order\n    # Here we only list symbolic mapping: control c preserved; quantum superposition.\n\nSetup & Resources:\n  Logical modes:\n    \u2022 Control qudit: mode 0 in D frequency bins {\u03c9\u2080\u2026\u03c9_{D\u22121}}, \u0394\u03c9\u2248THz.  \n    \u2022 Three polarization qubits forming two swap stages:  \n        \u2013 S\u2081 \u2192 modes (1,2): Bell pair between A (mode 1) and C (mode 2).  \n        \u2013 S\u2082 \u2192 modes (3,4): Bell pair between heralding.\n\nProtocol:\n  \u2022 Charlie inputs modes {0_freq,2_pol,3_pol,5_pol} plus ancillas {7,8} into one optimized linear-optics network.  \n  \u2022 The network implements a controlled supermap: if control=\u03c9_k, perform the k-th swap chain out of D options\u2014for example:  \n       k=0: no swap (identity on A\u2013B),  \n       k=1: swap S\u2081\u2192S\u2083 (two-stage chain C\u2192D),  \n       k=2: swap S\u2081 only (A\u2013C) then leave D\u2013B,  \n       \u2026  \n       k=D\u22121: perform S\u2082\u2192S\u2083 first (D\u2192B) then S\u2081 (A\u2192C).  \n  \u2022 Condition on a specific two-click pattern at detectors on modes 7&8. Upon herald, modes 1 and 6 emerge carrying whatever entanglement was routed: from zero up to two swaps, as coherently programmed by the THz qudit.\n\nAbstract Target Quantum:\n  For each k\u2208{0\u2026D\u22121}, define the 8-photon amplitude mapping  \n    |k; \u03a6\u2081\u2082; \u03a6\u2083\u2084; \u03a6\u2085\u2086\u27e9 \u2192 |k\u27e9\u2080\u2009\u2297\u2009|Entangled_AB^{(k)}\u27e9  \n  where |Entangled_AB^{(k)}\u27e9 is the Bell state between modes 1 & 6 resulting from the k-th swap sequence.     "output": "Description:\n  Polariton\u2010Eigenstate Analyzer\u2014A linear\u2010optics measurement device that projects a single photon, whose quantum information is encoded in a polarization qubit (|H\u27e9\u2261ground, |V\u27e9\u2261excited) and a two\u2010bin THz\u2010frequency qubit (|\u03c9\u2080\u27e9\u2261n=0, |\u03c9\u2081\u27e9\u2261n=1), onto the four eigenstates of the resonant Jaynes\u2013Cummings Hamiltonian:\n     \u2022 Two \u201cdark\u201d states: |H,\u03c9\u2080\u27e9 and |V,\u03c9\u2081\u27e9  \n     \u2022 Two polaritonic states:  \n         |LP\u27e9 = (|V,\u03c9\u2080\u27e9 \u2212 |H,\u03c9\u2081\u27e9)/\u221a2  \n         |UP\u27e9 = (|V,\u03c9\u2080\u27e9 + |H,\u03c9\u2081\u27e9)/\u221a2  \n\n  This analyzer thus performs a basis change into the polariton eigenbasis, directly probing strong light\u2013matter coupling via a static, heralded linear\u2010optics network.\n\nProtocol Sketch:\n  1) Inputs: one single\u2010photon source carrying the unknown pol\u2297freq state on modes 0 (polarization H/V) and 1 (frequency \u03c9\u2080/\u03c9\u2081).  \n  2) Two ancilla single photons (modes 2&3) are injected to enable a joint measurement.  \n  3) All four photons pass through a 6\u00d76 optimized beam\u2010splitter/phase\u2010shifter network.  \n  4) Two detectors herald the successful projection; the other two detectors (modes 4&5) click in one of four exclusive patterns, each uniquely identifying one eigenstate.\n\nAbstract Target Quantum Mapping:\n  Input basis |p,f\u27e9 \u2192 Detection outcome d\u2208{00,01,10,11}:\n    \u201c00\u201d \u2194 |H,\u03c9\u2080\u27e9  \n    \u201c01\u201d \u2194 |V,\u03c9\u2081\u27e9  \n    \u201c10\u201d \u2194 |LP\u27e9 = (|10\u27e9 \u2212 |01\u27e9)/\u221a2  \n    \u201c11\u201d \u2194 |UP\u27e9 = (|10\u27e9 + |01\u27e9)/\u221a2\n\nPytheus\u2010Config Template:\n{\n  'description': 'Polariton\u2010Eigenstate Analyzer: project pol\u2297THz\u2010freq qubit onto JC eigenbasis',\n  'foldername': 'polariton_jc_analyzer',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 30,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_pre': 3,                  # one system photon + two ancillas\n  'num_anc': 2,                  # two ancilla photons to herald\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 20,\n  'single_emitters': [0,1,2],    # modes 0&1 = system DOFs, mode 2&3 = ancillas\n  'in_nodes': [0,1],             # system modes: polarization & freq\n  'anc_detectors': [2,3],        # ancilla detectors for herald\n  'out_nodes': [4,5],            # two detectors discriminating the four outcomes\n  'target_quantum': [\n    '00 00 1.0+0.0j',            # input 00\u2192detector pattern \u201c00\u201d\n    '11 01 1.0+0.0j',            # input 11\u2192\u201c01\u201d\n    '10 10 0.70710678+0.0j',     # LP\u2010component of 10\u2192\u201c10\u201d\n    '01 10 -0.70710678+0.0j',\n    '10 11 0.70710678+0.0j',     # UP\u2010component of 10\u2192\u201c11\u201d\n    '01 11 0.70710678+0.0j'\n  ],\n  'removed_connections': []\n}\n\nVisualization:\n  Single\u2010photon emitter (mode 0,1) \u2193  \n  Ancillas (modes 2,3) \u2193  \n sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, and photon\u2010counting heralds\u2014no feedback or cavities needed."

    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Quantum tomography of structured light patterns from simple intensity\n  measurements\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Iso-entangled bases and joint measurements\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Quantum Kinetic Rates within the Nonequilibrium Steady State\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). Then teleport that qubit onward.\n    b) Hybrid Node Network Emulating THz Strong Coupling via Ancillary High\u2010Dimensional Mode:\n       \u2013 Build a three\u2010node network A\u2013C\u2013B. A\u2013C share a 2D Bell pair, C\u2013B share a D\u2010dimensional Bell pair (D\u226b2), where the extra dimensions emulate matter excitations at THz energy splittings. At C, perform a joint measurement across the 2D and D\u2010dimensional systems (a \u201chybrid\u201d Bell measurement) that enacts an entanglement swap and simulates the strong coupling between light (2D) and matter (D\u2010dimensional THz manifold). This teleports A\u2019s qubit into B\u2019s high\u2010D mode.\n    c) Teleportation of a Qubit through Simulated Polaritonic Modes Using Ancillary THz\u2010Bin Photons:\n       \u2013 Prepare two three\u2010party entangled GHZ\u2010like links: one in polarization and one in THz\u2010frequency bins. No existing Pytheus target implements an isometry from two independently held qubits into one higher\u2010dimensional mode in this way.\n  Step 5: This idea is feasible in Pytheus because:\n    \u2022 All modes (polarization qubits and abstract THz\u2010frequency bins) are described purely abstractly.\n    \u2022 The target is a transformation (isometry) between modes, not state generation.\n    \u2022 It uses only probabilistic pair\u2010sources, linear optics, and joint measurements\u2014Pytheus\u2019s supported primitives.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription: Entanglement \u201cfunneling\u201d of two polarization qubits into one THz\u2010frequency qudit via a single joint swap measurement.\n\nExplanation:\n We label modes as follows:\n  \u2013 Node A holds photon 0 in polarization (qubit A).\n  \u2013 Node B holds photon 1 in polarization (qubit B).\n  \u2013 Node C holds photons 2&3: photon 2 is entangled in polarization with A, photon 3 entangled in polarization with B. These come from two independent Bell\u2010pair sources S1 (modes 0&2) and S2 (modes 1&3).\n  \u2013 Node D will output a single photon 4 encoded into four abstract frequency bins {\u03c90,\u03c91,\u03c92,\u03c93} with bin spacing \u0394\u03c9 \u2248 THz, i.e. a ququart.\n\nGoal: implement the isometry\n  |i\u27e9\u2080|j\u27e9\u2081 \u2192 |\u03c9_{2i + j}\u27e9\u2084   for i,j \u2208 {0,1},\nso that the joint polarization state of A&B is coherently \u201cfunnelled\u201d into one higher\u2010dimensional THz mode at D.\n\nProtocol (entanglement\u2010swap style):\n  1) Prepare S1: a polarization Bell pair on modes 0 & 2: |00>+|11>.\n  2) Prepare S2: a polarization Bell pair on modes 1 & 3: |00>+|11>.\n  3) At node C, interfere photons 2&3 in a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics network engineered to implement a joint measurement whose successful heralding projects those two photons onto one of four predefined two\u2010qubit Bell\u2010like basis states. The outcome determines which of the four frequency bins \u03c9_k at mode 4 carries the combined label (2i+j).\n  4) Conditioned on the heralded detection at C, photon 4 emerges in the target ququart state |\u03c9_{2i + j}\u27e9\u2084, faithfully representing the original two\u2010qubit state.\n\nAbstract Target Quantum:\n We define a four\u2010mode computational basis for modes 0,1,4:\n   { |0\u20800\u2081\u03c9\u2080\u2084>, |0\u20801\u2081\u03c9\u2081\u2084>, |1\u20800\u2081\u03c9\u2082\u2084>, |1\u20801\u2081\u03c9\u2083\u2084> } \n(with appropriate complex phases set by the joint measurement outcomes).\n The target amplitude list is then the identity map on that basis.\n\nConfig Sketch:\n  num_pre: 2                      # two pair sources\n  num_anc: 0                      # no extra ancillas beyond 4 photons\n  single_emitters: []\n  removed_connections: []         # sources only to their designated pairs\n  loss_func: 'cr'\n  samples: 10\n  target_quantum: [\n    '000\u03c90',  # basis mapping, indices are abstract labels\n    '011\u03c91',\n    '100\u03c92',\n    '111\u03c93'\n  ]\n  in_nodes: [0,1]\n  out_nodes: [4]\n  anc_detectors: [2,3]\n  # Any required \u201clookup table\u201d for detector patterns \u2192 bin index is part of the post\u2010processing.\n\nVisual Layout:\n  S1 \u2192 (0,2_pol)  \n               \u2198 \n                 \u25b6\u2500[4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics joint\u2010measurement block at C]\u2500\u2197\u2500 heralded detectors (2,3)\n               \u2197  \n  S2 \u2192 (1,3_pol)  \n\n  Post-selected on one of 4 click-patterns at detectors 2&3, output mode 4 emerges in one of the four frequency bins \u03c9\u2080\u2026\u03c9\u2083.\n\nThis network realizes a nontrivial conversion: it \u201cstrongly couples\u201d two polarization qubits (matter\u2010like excitations) into one THz\u2010spaced frequency\u2010bin photon (light\u2010like output). It can be generalized by:\n  \u2013 Increasing input qubit counts (e.g. three qubits \u2192 one 8\u2010bin frequency octit).\n  \u2013 Swapping chains of such funnels to build high\u2010throughput THz-bandwidth quantum routers.\n  \u2013 Emulating multi-exciton polaritonic networks in an all\u2010linear\u2010optics framework.\n\nThe Expert can use Pytheus to discover the exact beam-splitter and phase settings realizing the 4\u00d74 joint\u2010measurement block.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The protocol duplicates the known two\u2010qubit to four\u2010level frequency\u2010bin mapping via a single joint measurement and adds only a change of DOF. The control qubit |c\u27e9_freq \u2208{|\u03c9\u2080>,|\u03c9\u2081>} (\u0394\u03c9\u2248THz) coherently routes the order in which Charlie performs two Bell\u2010measurements\n    \u2022 Swap\u20101 at node C on modes (A\u2013C, C\u2013D)\n    \u2022 Swap\u20102 at node D on modes (C\u2013D, D\u2013B)\n  When c=\u03c9\u2080 the network does Swap\u20101\u2192Swap\u20102; when c=\u03c9\u2081 it does Swap\u20102\u2192Swap\u20101. It directly captures the hallmark of strong light\u2013matter coupling: coherent energy exchange.  \n  Step 3: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework: we need only three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources (two to prepare the polarization and frequency qubit inputs, one to supply ancillas), two ancilla photons for heralding, linear optics beam\u2010splitters and phase shifters, and photon\u2010counting detectors. No cavities, feedback, or forbidden hyper\u2010 or hybrid\u2010entanglement appear.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  Heralded implementation of the resonant Jaynes\u2013Cummings unitary U_JC(\u03b8) between a polarization qubit and a two\u2010bin THz\u2010frequency mode.  This realizes a coherent exchange of one excitation, emulating strong light\u2013matter coupling at THz spacing.\n\nExplanation:\n  Modes & Resources:\n    \u2022 Two logical qubits:  \n        \u2013 Bell\u2010partner on 2.  \n        S\u2082 \u2192 modes (1,3) prepare frequency\u2010bin qubit on 1 and its Bell\u2010partner on 3.  \n        S\u2083 \u2192 modes (4,5) prepare ancilla pair for heralding.  \n\n  Target unitary U_JC(\u03b8) in the four\u2010dimensional basis  \n    { |H,\u03c9\u2080\u27e9, |H,\u03c9\u2081\u27e9, |V,\u03c9\u2080\u27e9, |V,\u03c9\u2081\u27e9 }:  \n    \u2013 It acts as a rotation by \u03b8 in the single\u2010excitation subspace spanned by {|H,\u03c9\u2080\u27e9, |V,\u03c9\u2081\u27e9}, i.e.  \n         |H,\u03c9\u2080\u27e9 \u2192 cos\u03b8\u2009|V,\u03c9\u2081\u27e9  \n      and leaves |H,\u03c9\u2081\u27e9 and |V,\u03c9\u2080\u27e9 unchanged.  \n    \u2013 This embodies half\u2010Rabi oscillation of a qubit strongly coupled to a bosonic THz mode.\n\n  Protocol:\n    \u2022 Inject modes 0\u20131 (logical qubits) and ancillas 4\u20135 into a tailored 6\u00d76 linear\u2010optics network.  \n    \u2022 Post\u2010select on a specific two\u2010click pattern at detectors on modes 4&5 (herald).  \n    \u2022 Upon herald, photons exit on modes 2 (pol output) and 3 (freq output) having undergone U_JC(\u03b8).\n\nPytheus Config I propose a photonic quantum\u2010programmable gate: use a THz\u2010frequency qubit as a program register to control which single\u2010qubit unitary is applied to a polarization qubit. As a concrete first step, implement a heralded controlled\u2010Hadamard: if the THz qubit is in |\u03c9\u2080\u3009 do nothing to the polarization qubit; if in |\u03c9\u2081\u3009 apply H. This is a new two\u2010qubit controlled\u2010unitary network, not previously found in Pytheus\u2019s library, and directly mimics strong light\u2013matter coupling where the matter state (THz) programs the photon\u2019s evolution. It uses only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics and heralded photon counting\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s scope\u2014and generalizes immediately to higher\u2010D programmable gates or cascaded programmable networks.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  Heralded controlled\u2010Hadamard gate between a THz\u2010frequency\u2010bin qubit (program) and a polarization qubit (data). When the program is in bin \u03c9\u2080, the polarization qubit is left untouched; when in bin \u03c9\u2081, a Hadamard H is applied.  \n  This simulates a strong light\u2013matter coupling in which the matter\u2019s THz\u2010state coherently controls the photon\u2019s mode transformation.\n\nResources & Modes:\n  \u2013 Program qubit: half of a Bell pair S\u2081 on modes (0_freq,4_freq), encoding |\u03c9\u2080\u03c9\u2080\u3009+|\u03c9\u2081\u03c9\u2081\u3009.  \n  \u2013 Data qubit: half of a Bell pair S\u2082 on modes (1_pol,5_pol), encoding |HH\u3009+|VV\u3009.  \n  \u2013 Ancillas: one Bell pair S\u2083 on modes (6,7) for heralding.  \n\nProtocol:\n  1) Inject modes 0\u20131 (the two logical qubits) and ancilla photons 6\u20137 into a 6\u00d76 linear\u2010optics network optimized to realize the controlled\u2010H map.  \n  2) Post\u2010select on a specific two\u2010click pattern at detectors on ancilla modes 6&7.  \n  3) Upon herald, the remaining photons exit on modes 4 (program) unchanged and 5 (data) having undergone H if and only if the program was in \u03c9\u2081.  \n\nAbstract Target Mapping on basis |c,t\u27e9 (c\u2208{0,1} for \u03c9\u2080,\u03c9\u2081;
